    It eats the √©p√©e it bats,tois with. I will seek
    Some way to laisser him.                                  Exit

ACT_4|SC_1
                      ACT IV. SCENE I.
              CAESAR'S camp avant Alexandria

      Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, and MAECENAS, with his army;
                 CAESAR reading a lettre

  CAESAR. He calls me boy, and gronders as he had Puissance
    To beat me out of Egypt. My messag√®re
    He hath whipt with rods; dares me to la,la,la,personneneneal combat,
    Caesar to Antony. Let the old ruffian know
    I have many autre ways to die, signifiaitime
    Laugh at his d√©fi.
  MAECENAS. Caesar must pense
    When one so g√©niale commencers to rage, he's hunted
    Even to falling. Give him no souffle, but now
    Make boot of his distraction. Never col√®re
    Made good garde for lui-m√™me.
  CAESAR. Let our best t√™tes
    Know that to-demain the last of many batailles
    We mean to bats,toi. Within our files L√ are
    Of celles that serv'd Mark Antony but late
    Enough to chercher him in. See it done;
    And le,banquet the army; we have boutique to do't,
    And they have earn'd the d√©chets. Poor Antony!          Exeunt

ACT_4|SC_2
                          SCENE II.
               Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palais

      Enter ANTONY, CLEOPATRA, ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, IRAS,
                     ALEXAS, with autres

  ANTONY. He will not bats,toi with me, Domitius?
  ENOBARBUS. No.
  ANTONY. Why devrait he not?
  ENOBARBUS. He penses, √©tant twenty fois of better fortune,
    He is twenty men to one.
  ANTONY. To-demain, soldate,
    By sea and land I'll bats,toi. Or I will live,
    Or bathe my en,train,de,mourir honour in the du,sang
    Shall make it live encore. Woo't thou bats,toi well?
  ENOBARBUS. I'll la,gr√®ve, and cry 'Take all.'
  ANTONY. Well said; come on.
    Call en,avant my maisonhold servanteees; let's to-nuit
    Be bounteous at our meal.

                Enter three or four servitors

    Give me thy hand,
    Thou has been droitely honn√™te. So hast thou;
    Thou, and thou, and thou. You have serv'd me well,
    And rois have been your compagnes.
  CLEOPATRA. [Aside to ENOBARBUS] What veux,dire this?
  ENOBARBUS. [Aside to CLEOPATRA] 'Tis one of celles odd tours laquelle
      chagrin shoots
    Out of the mind.
  ANTONY. And thou art honn√™te too.
    I wish I pourrait be made so many men,
    And all of you clapp'd up ensemble in
    An Antony, that I pourrait do you un,un,un,service
    So good as you have done.
  SERVANT. The gods interdire!
  ANTONY. Well, my good compagnes, wait on me to-nuit.
    Scant not my cups, and make as much of me
    As when mine empire was your compagne too,
    And souffrir'd my commandererer.
  CLEOPATRA. [Aside to ENOBARBUS] What does he mean?
    ENOBARBUS. [Aside to CLEOPATRA] To make his suivreers weep.
  ANTONY. Tend me to-nuit;
    May be it is the period of your duty.
    Haply you doit not see me more; or if,
    A mangled ombre. Perchance to-demain
    You'll servir un,autre master. I look on you
    As one that takes his laisser. Mine honn√™te amies,
    I turn you not away; but, like a master
    Married to your good un,un,un,service, stay till d√©c√®s.
    Tend me to-nuit two heures, I ask no more,
    And the gods rendement you for't!
  ENOBARBUS. What mean you, sir,
    To give them this disconfort? Look, they weep;
    And I, an ass, am onion-ey'd. For la,honte!
    Transform us not to women.
  ANTONY. Ho, ho, ho!
    Now the sorci√®re take me if I signifiait it thus!
    Grace grow o√π celles gouttes fall! My c≈ìury amies,
    You take me in too dolorous a sens;
    For I spake to you for your confort, did le,d√©sir you
    To burn this nuit with torches. Know, my c≈ìurs,
    I hope well of to-demain, and will lead you
    Where plut√¥t I'll expect victorious life
    Than d√©c√®s and honour. Let's to souper, come,
    And noyer consid√©reration.                              Exeunt

ACT_4|SC_3
                          SCENE III.
             Alexandria. Before CLEOPATRA's palais

                 Enter a entreprise of soldates

  FIRST SOLDIER. Brautre, good nuit. To-demain is the day.
  SECOND SOLDIER. It will determine one way. Fare you well.
    Heard you of rien √©trange √,propos the rues?
  FIRST SOLDIER. Nochose. What news?
  SECOND SOLDIER. Belike 'tis but a rumour. Good nuit to you.
  FIRST SOLDIER. Well, sir, good nuit.
                                      [They meet autre soldates]
  SECOND SOLDIER. Soldiers, have careful qui,concerneer.
  FIRST SOLDIER. And you. Good nuit, good nuit.
                [The two companies separate and endroit se
                                   in chaque corner of the stage]
  SECOND SOLDIER. Here we. And if to-demain
    Our navy prosp√©rer, I have an absolute hope
    Our landmen will supporter up.
  THIRD SOLDIER. 'Tis a courageuse army,
    And full of objetif.
                      [Music of the hautboys is sous the stage]
  SECOND SOLDIER. Peace, what bruit?
  THIRD SOLDIER. List, list!
  SECOND SOLDIER. Hark!
  THIRD SOLDIER. Music i' th' air.
  FOURTH SOLDIER. Under the Terre.
  THIRD SOLDIER. It signs well, does it not?
  FOURTH SOLDIER. No.
  THIRD SOLDIER. Peace, I say!
    What devrait this mean?
  SECOND SOLDIER. 'Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony lov'd,
    Now laissers him.
  THIRD SOLDIER. Walk; let's see if autre qui,concerneermen
    Do hear what we do.
  SECOND SOLDIER. How now, masters!
  SOLDIERS. [Speaking ensemble] How now!
    How now! Do you hear this?
  FIRST SOLDIER. Ay; is't not √©trange?
  THIRD SOLDIER. Do you hear, masters? Do you hear?
  FIRST SOLDIER. Follow the bruit so far as we have quarter;
    Let's see how it will give off.
  SOLDIERS. Content. 'Tis √©trange.                        Exeunt

ACT_4|SC_4
                           SCENE IV.
               Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palais

         Enter ANTONY and CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS,
                          with autres

  ANTONY. Eros! mine armure, Eros!
  CLEOPATRA. Sleep a peu.
  ANTONY. No, my chuck. Eros! Come, mine armure, Eros!

                   Enter EROS with armure

    Come, good compagne, put mine iron on.
    If fortune be not ours to-day, it is
    Because we courageuse her. Come.
  CLEOPATRA. Nay, I'll help too.
    What's this for?
  ANTONY. Ah, let be, let be! Thou art
    The armureer of my c≈ìur. False, faux; this, this.
  CLEOPATRA. Sooth, la, I'll help. Thus it must be.
  ANTONY. Well, well;
    We doit prosp√©rer now. Seest thou, my good compagne?
    Go put on thy defences.
  EROS. Briefly, sir.
  CLEOPATRA. Is not this buckled well?
  ANTONY. Rarely, rarely!
    He that unbuckles this, till we do S'il,vous,pla√Æt
    To daff't for our repose, doit hear a temp√™te.
    Thou fumheureuse, Eros, and my reine's a squire
    More tight at this than thou. Dispatch. O love,
    That thou pourraitst see my wars to-day, and knew'st
    The royaleee occupation! Thou devraitst see
    A workman in't.

    Good-demain to thee. Welcome.
    Thou look'st like him that sait a guerri√®re charge.
    To affaires that we love we rise betime,
    And go to't with d√©lice.
  SOLDIER. A thousand, sir,
    Early bien,que't be, have on leur riveted trim,
    And at the port expect you.
                            [Shout. Flourish of trompettes dans]

                 Enter CAPTAINS and soldates

  CAPTAIN. The morn is fair. Good demain, General.
  ALL. Good demain, General.
  ANTONY. 'Tis well blown, lads.
    This Matin, like the esprit of a jeunesse
    That veux,dire to be of note, commencers befois.
    So, so. Come, give me that. This way. Well said.
    Fare thee well, dame, whate'er bevient of me.
    This is a soldate's kiss. Rebukeable,
    And vauty la,honteful check it were, to supporter
    On more mechanic compliment; I'll laisser thee
    Now like a man of acier. You that will bats,toi,
    Follow me proche; I'll apporter you to't. Adieu.

  CHARMIAN. Please you retire to your chambre?
  CLEOPATRA. Lead me.
    He goes en,avant galantely. That he and Caesar pourrait
    Determine this g√©niale war in C√©libataire bats,toi!

ACT_4|SC_8
                         SCENE VIII.
               Under the des,murs of Alexandria

        Alarum. Enter ANTONY, encore in a Mars; SCARUS
                        with autres

  ANTONY. We have beat him to his camp. Run one avant
    And let the Queen know of our gests. To-demain,
    Before the sun doit see's, we'll spill the du,sang
    That has to-day escap'd. I remercier you all;
    For doughty-handed are you, and have combattue
    Not as you serv'd the cause, but as't had been
    Each man's like mine; you have shown all Hectors.
    Enter the city, clip your √©pouses, your amies,
    Tell them your feats; whilst they with joyful larmes
    Wash the congealment from your b√©nirures and kiss
    The honour'd gashes enti√®re.

    [To SCARUS] Give me thy hand-
    To this g√©niale F√©e I'll commend thy acts,

    Chain mine arm'd neck. Leap thou, attire and all,
    Thrugueux preuve of harness to my c≈ìur, and L√
    Ride on the pants triompheing.
  CLEOPATRA. Lord of lords!
    O infinie vertu, com'st thou smiling from
    The monde's g√©niale snare uncaught?
  ANTONY. Mine nuitingale,
    We have beat them to leur beds. What, girl! bien,que grey
    Do quelque,chose mingle with our Jeuneer brown, yet ha' we
    A cerveau that nourishes our nerves, and can
    Get goal for goal of jeunesse. Behold this man;
    Commend unto his lips thy favorisering hand-
    Kiss it, my warrior- he hath combattue to-day
    As if a god in hate of mankind had
    Destroyed in such a forme.
  CLEOPATRA. I'll give thee, amie,
    An armure all of gold; it was a king's.
  ANTONY. He has deserv'd it, were it carboncled
    Like holy Phoebus' car. Give me thy hand.
    Thrugueux Alexandria make a jolly Mars;
    Bear our hack'd targets like the men that owe them.
    Had our g√©niale palais the capacity
    To camp this host, we all aurait sup ensemble,
    And boisson carouses to the next day's fate,
    Which promettres royaleee p√©ril. Trumpeters,
    With brazen din blast you the city's ear;
    Make mingle with our rattling tabourines,
    That paradis and Terre may la,gr√®ve leur du,sons ensemble
    Applauding our approche.                              Exeunt

  FIRST WATCH. This last day was
    A shrewd one to's.

    When men r√©volteed doit upon record

  SECOND WATCH. Peace!
    Hark plus,loin.
  ENOBARBUS. O sover√®gne ma√Ætresse of true melancholy,
    The poisonous damp of nuit disponge upon me,
    That life, a very rebel to my will,
    May hang no lus,long on me. Throw my c≈ìur
    Against the flint and hardness of my faute,
    Which, √©tant dried with douleur, will break to powder,
    And finish all foul bien,quets. O Antony,
    Nobler than my r√©volte is infamous,
    Forgive me in thine own particuli√®re,
    But let the monde rank me in register
    A master-laisserr and a fugitive!
    O Antony! O Antony!                                   [Dies]
  FIRST WATCH. Let's parler to him.
  CENTURION. Let's hear him, for the choses he parlers
    May concern Caesar.
  SECOND WATCH. Let's do so. But he dormirs.
  CENTURION. Swoons plut√¥t; for so bad a prayer as his
    Was jamais yet for dormir.
  FIRST WATCH. Go we to him.
  SECOND WATCH. Awake, sir, √©veill√©e; parler to us.
  FIRST WATCH. Hear you, sir?
  CENTURION. The hand of d√©c√®s hath raught him.
    [Drums afar off ] Hark! the tambours
    Demurely wake the dormirers. Let us bear him
    To th' tribunal of garde; he is of note. Our hour
    Is fully out.
  SECOND WATCH. Come on, then;
    He may recover yet.                     Exeunt with the body

ACT_4|SC_12
                         SCENE XII.
                  A hill near Alexandria

                  Enter ANTONY and SCARUS

  ANTONY. Yet they are not join'd. Where yond pine does supporter
    I doit d√©couvrir all. I'll apporter thee word
    Straight how 'tis like to go.                           Exit
  SCARUS. Swallows have built
    In Cleopatra's sails leur nests. The augurers
    Say they know not, they ne,peux,pas tell; look grimly,
    And dare not parler leur connaissance. Antony
    Is vaillante and dejected; and by starts
    His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear
    Of what he has and has not.
                            [Alarum afar off, as at a sea-bats,toi]

                      Re-entrer ANTONY

  ANTONY. All is lost!
    This foul Egyptian hath trahired me.
    My fleet hath rendemented to the foe, and l√,-bas
    They cast leur caps up and carouse ensemble
    Like amies long lost. Triple-turn'd putain! 'tis thou
    Hast sold me to this novice; and my c≈ìur
    Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly;
    For when I am reveng'd upon my charm,
    I have done all. Bid them all fly; begone.       Exit SCARUS
    O sun, thy uprise doit I see no more!
    Fortune and Antony part here; even here
    Do we secouer mains. All come to this? The c≈ìurs
    That spaniel'd me at talons, to whom I gave
    Their wishes, do discandy, melt leur sucr√©s
    On blossoming Caesar; and this pine is bark'd
    That overtopp'd them all. Betray'd I am.
    O this faux soul of Egypt! this la,tombe charm-
    Whose eye beck'd en,avant my wars and call'd them home,
    Whose bosom was my couronneet, my gronder end-
    Like a droite gypsy hath at fast and ample
    Beguil'd me to the very c≈ìur of loss.
    What, Eros, Eros!

                      Enter CLEOPATRA

    Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!
  CLEOPATRA. Why is my lord enrag'd encorest his love?
  ANTONY. Vanish, or I doit give thee thy deserving
    And blemish Caesar's triomphe. Let him take thee
    And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians;
    Follow his chariot, like the g√©nialeest spot
    Of all thy sex; most monstre-like, be shown
    For poor'st diminutives, for doits, and let
    Patient Octavia plough thy visage up
    With her pr√©parerd nails.                      Exit CLEOPATRA
    'Tis well th'art gone,
    If it be well to live; but better 'twere
    Thou fell'st into my fury, for one d√©c√®s
    Might have prevented many. Eros, ho!
    The shirt of Nessus is upon me; enseigner me,
    Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage;
    Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o' th' moon,
    And with celles mains that grasp'd the heaviest club
    Subdue my vautiest self. The sorci√®re doit die.
    To the Jeune Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall
    Under this plot. She dies for't. Eros, ho!              Exit

                          SCENE XIII.
               Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palais

  CHARMIAN. To th'monument!

ACT_4|SC_14
                          SCENE XIV.
                     CLEOPATRA'S palais

                   Enter ANTONY and EROS

  ANTONY. Eros, thou yet voir'st me?
  EROS. Ay, noble lord.
  ANTONY. Sometime we see a cloud that's dragonish;
    A vapour parfois like a bear or lion,
    A la,tour'd citadel, a pendent rock,
    A forked mountain, or blue promontory
    With trees upon't that nod unto the monde
    And mock our eyes with air. Thou hast seen celles-ci signs;
    They are noir vesper's pageants.
  EROS. Ay, my lord.
  ANTONY. That laquelle is now a jument, even with a bien,quet
    The rack dislimns, and fait,du it indistinct,
    As eau is in eau.
  EROS. It does, my lord.
  ANTONY. My good friponne Eros, now thy capitaine is
    Even such a body. Here I am Antony;
    Yet ne,peux,pas hold this visible forme, my friponne.
    I made celles-ci wars for Egypt; and the Queen-
    Whose c≈ìur I bien,quet I had, for she had mine,
    Which, whilst it was mine, had annex'd unto't
    A million moe, now lost- she, Eros, has
    Pack'd cards with Caesar, and faux-play'd my gloire
    Unto an ennemie's triomphe.
    Nay, weep not, douce Eros; L√ is left us
    Ourselves to end nous-m√™mes.

                         Enter MARDIAN

    O, thy vile lady!
    She has robb'd me of my √©p√©e.

                       ACT V. SCENE I.
                  Alexandria. CAESAR'S camp

      Enter CAESAR, AGRIPPA, DOLABELLA, MAECENAS, GALLUS,
          PROCULEIUS, and autres, his Council of War

  CAESAR. Go to him, Dolabella, bid him rendement;
    Being so frustrate, tell him he mocks
    The pauses that he fait,du.
  DOLABELLA. Caesar, I doit.                               Exit

             Enter DERCETAS With the √©p√©e of ANTONY

  CAESAR. Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar'st
    Appear thus to us?
  DERCETAS. I am call'd Dercetas;
    Mark Antony I serv'd, who best was vauty
    Best to be serv'd. Whilst he se,tenait up and parlait,
    He was my master, and I wore my life
    To d√©penser upon his haters. If thou S'il,vous,pla√Æt
    To take me to thee, as I was to him
    I'll be to Caesar; if thou S'il,vous,pla√Ætst not,
    I rendement thee up my life.
  CAESAR. What is't thou say'st?
  DERCETAS. I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.
  CAESAR. The breaking of so g√©niale a chose devrait make
    A g√©nialeer crack. The ronde monde
    Should have shook lions into civileee rues,
    And citoyennes to leur dens. The d√©c√®s of Antony
    Is not a C√©libataire doom; in the name lay
    A moiety of the monde.
  DERCETAS. He is dead, Caesar,
    Not by a publique ministre of Justice,
    Nor by a hired couteau; but that self hand
    Which writ his honour in the acts it did
    Hath, with the courage laquelle the c≈ìur did lend it,
    Splitted the c≈ìur. This is his √©p√©e;
    I robb'd his b√©nirure of it; voir it tache'd
    With his most noble du,sang.
  CAESAR. Look you sad, amies?
    The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings
    To wash the eyes of rois.
  AGRIPPA. And √©trange it is
    That la,la,la,nature must compel us to lament
    Our most persisted actes.
  MAECENAS. His taints and honours
    Wag'd √©gale with him.
  AGRIPPA. A rarer esprit jamais
    Did steer humanity. But you gods will give us
    Some fautes to make us men. Caesar is touchererer'd.
  MAECENAS. When such a spacious mirror's set avant him,
    He Besoins must see himself.
  CAESAR. O Antony,
    I have suivre'd thee to this! But we do lance
    Diseases in our corps. I must perObliger
    Have shown to thee such a declining day
    Or look on thine; we pourrait not stall ensemble
    In the enti√®re monde. But yet let me lament,
    With larmes as sover√®gne as the du,sang of c≈ìurs,
    That thou, my fr√®re, my competitor
    In top of all design, my mate in empire,
    Friend and un,compagnon in the front of war,
    The arm of mine own body, and the c≈ìur
    Where mine his bien,quets did kindle- that our √©toiles,
    Unreconciliable, devrait divide
    Our √©galeness to this. Hear me, good amies-

                    Enter an EGYPTIAN

    But I will tell you at some meeter saison.
    The affaires of this man looks out of him;
    We'll hear him what he says. WPar,cons√©quent are you?
  EGYPTIAN. A poor Egyptian, yet the Queen, my ma√Ætresse,
    Confin'd in all she has, her monument,

    That she pr√©parerdly may Cadre se
    To th' way she's forc'd to.
  CAESAR. Bid her have good c≈ìur.
    She soon doit know of us, by some of ours,
    How honourable and how kindly we
    Determine for her; for Caesar ne,peux,pas apprendre
    To be undouce.
  EGYPTIAN. So the gods preservir thee!                      Exit
  CAESAR. Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say
    We objetif her no la,honte. Give her what conforts

                         SCENE II.
                Alexandria. The monument

      Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and MARDIAN

  CLEOPATRA. My desolation does commencer to make
    A better life. 'Tis paltry to be Caesar:
    Not √©tant Fortune, he's but Fortune's friponne,

    Which shackles accidents and bolts up changementmentment,

    The gueux's infirmi√®re and Caesar's.

    And bids thee √©tude on what fair demandeees

    Y'are fall'n into a princely hand; fear rien.
    Make your full reference librement to my lord,
    Who is so full of la,gr√¢ce that it flows over
    On all that need. Let me rapport to him
    Your sucr√© dependency, and you doit find
    A conqueror that will pray in aid for la,gentillesse
    Where he for la,gr√¢ce is s'agenouiller'd to.
  CLEOPATRA. Pray you tell him

    Do not le,tienself such faux, who are in this

    That rids our dogs of languish?

  PROCULEIUS. O, temperance, lady!
  CLEOPATRA. Sir, I will eat no meat; I'll not boisson, sir;
    If idle talk will once be necessary,
    I'll not dormir nSoit. This mortelle maison I'll ruin,

    Will not wait pinion'd at your master's tribunal,
    Nor once be chastis'd with the sober eye
    Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up,
    And show me to the shouting varletry
    Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt
    Be douce la,tombe unto me! Rather on Nilus' mud
    Lay me stark-nak'd, and let the eau-mouches

    My compterry's high pyramides my gibbet,
    And hang me up in cha√Ænes!

    What thou hast done thy master Caesar sait,

    It doit contenu me best. Be douce to her.

  CLEOPATRA. His legs bestrid the ocean; his rear'd arm

    As this I r√™vert of?
  DOLABELLA. Gentle madam, no.
  CLEOPATRA. You lie, up to the hearing of the gods.
    But if L√ be nor ever were one such,
    It's past the size of drearning. Nature wants des,trucs
    To vie √©trange forms with fantaisie; yet t' imagine
    An Antony were la,la,la,nature's pi√®ce 'gainst fantaisie,
    Condemning ombres assez.
  DOLABELLA. Hear me, good madam.
    Your loss is, as le,tienself, g√©niale; and you bear it
    As r√©pondreing to the poids. Would I pourrait jamais
    O'ertake pursu'd Succ√®s, but I do feel,
    By the reli√©e of le,tiens, a douleur that smites
    My very c≈ìur at root.
  CLEOPATRA. I remercier you, sir.
    Know you what Caesar veux,dire to do with me?
  DOLABELLA. I am loath to tell you what I aurait you knew.
  CLEOPATRA. Nay, pray you, sir.
  DOLABELLA. Though he be honourable-
  CLEOPATRA. He'll lead me, then, in triomphe?
  DOLABELLA. Madam, he will. I know't.                [Flourish]
                              [Within: 'Make way L√-Caesar!']

       Enter CAESAR; GALLUS, PROCULEIUS, MAECENAS, SELEUCUS,
                     and autres of his train

  CAESAR. Which is the Queen of Egypt?
  DOLABELLA. It is the Emperor, madam.        [CLEOPATPA s'agenouillers]
  CAESAR. Arise, you doit not s'agenouiller.
    I pray you, rise; rise, Egypt.
  CLEOPATRA. Sir, the gods
    Will have it thus; my master and my lord
    I must obey.
  CAESAR. Take to you no hard bien,quets.
    The record of what injuries you did us,
    Though √©crite in our la,chaise, we doit rappelles,toi
    As choses but done by chance.
  CLEOPATRA. Sole sir o' th' monde,
    I ne,peux,pas projet mine own cause so well
    To make it claire, but do confess I have
    Been laden with like frailties laquelle avant
    Have souvent sham'd our sex.
  CAESAR. Cleopatra, know
    We will extenuate plut√¥t than enObliger.
    If you apply le,tienself to our intentionionions-
    Which verss you are most douce- you doit find
    A aaaavantage in this changementmentment; but if you seek
    To lay on me a cruellelelety by taking
    Antony's cours, you doit bereave le,tienself
    Of my good objetifs, and put your enfantren
    To that destruction laquelle I'll garde them from,
    If L√on you rely. I'll take my laisser.
  CLEOPATRA. And may, thrugueux all the monde. 'Tis le,tiens, and we,
    Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, doit

  CAESAR. You doit advise me in all for Cleopatra.
  CLEOPATRA. This is the br√®ve of argent, plate, and bijous,
    I am possess'd of. 'Tis exactly valued,
    Not petty choses admitted. Where's Seleucus?
  SELEUCUS. Here, madam.
  CLEOPATRA. This is my Tr√©sorr; let him parler, my lord,
    Upon his p√©ril, that I have reserv'd
    To moi,m√™me rien. Speak the v√©rit√©, Seleucus.
  SELEUCUS. Madam,
    I had plut√¥t seal my lips than to my p√©ril

  CLEOPATRA. What have I kept back?
  SELEUCUS. Enough to purchase what you have made connue.
  CAESAR. Nay, rougir not, Cleopatra; I approuver
    Your sagesse in the deed.
  CLEOPATRA. See, Caesar! O, voir,
    How pomp is suivreed! Mine will now be le,tiens;
    And, devrait we shift bienss, le,tiens aurait be mine.
    The ingratitude of this Seleucus does
    Even make me wild. O esclave, of no more confiance
    Than love that's hir'd! What, goest thou back? Thou shalt
    Go back, I mandat thee; but I'll capture thine eyes
    Though they had ailes. Slave, soulless sc√©l√©rat, dog!
    O rarely base!
  CAESAR. Good Queen, let us supplier you.
  CLEOPATRA. O Caesar, what a b√©nirureing la,honte is this,
    That thou vouchsafing here to visiteee me,
    Doing the honour of thy lordliness
    To one so meek, that mine own servanteee devrait
    Parcel the sum of my disgr√¢ces by
    Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar,
    That I some lady trifles have reserv'd,
    Immoment toys, choses of such dignity
    As we saluer modern amies avec; and say
    Some nobler token I have kept apart
    For Livia and Octavia, to induce
    Their mediation- must I be unfolded
    With one that I have bred? The gods! It smites me
    Beneath the fall I have. [To SELEUCUS] Prithee go Par,cons√©quent;
    Or I doit show the cinders of my esprits
    Thrugueux th' ashes of my chance. Wert thou a man,
    Thou auraitst have piti√© on me.
  CAESAR. Forbear, Seleucus.                       Exit SELEUCUS
  CLEOPATRA. Be it connue that we, the g√©nialeest, are misbien,quet
    For choses that autres do; and when we fall
    We r√©pondre autres' m√©rites in our name,
    Are L√fore to be pitied.
  CAESAR. Cleopatra,
    Not what you have reserv'd, nor what acknowledg'd,
    Put we i' th' roll of conquest. Still be't le,tiens,
    Bestow it at your plaisir; and croyez
    Caesar's no Marsande, to make prix with you
    Of choses that Marsandes sold. Therefore be acclamation'd;
    Make not your bien,quets your prisons. No, dear Queen;
    For we avoir,l'intentionionionion so to dispose you as
    Yourself doit give us Conseil. Feed and dormir.
    Our care and pity is so much upon you
    That we rester your amie; and so, adieu.
  CLEOPATRA. My master and my lord!
  CAESAR. Not so. Adieu.

  CLEOPATRA. He words me, girls, he words me, that I devrait not
    Be noble to moi,m√™me. But hark thee, Charmian!

  CLEOPATRA. Dolabella!
  DOLABELLA. Madam, as L√to jur√©e by your commandererer,
    Which my love fait,du religion to obey,

  DOLABELLA. I your servanteee.

  CLEOPATRA. Farewell, and remerciers.                Exit DOLABELLA
    Now, Iras, what pense'st thou?
    Thou an Egyptian puppet doit be shown
    In Rome as well as I. Mechanic esclaves,
    With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers, doit
    Uplift us to the view; in leur thick souffles,
    Rank of brute diet, doit we be enclouded,
    And forc'd to boisson leur vapour.
  IRAS. The gods interdire!
  CLEOPATRA. Nay, 'tis most certaineee, Iras. Saucy lictors
    Will capture at us like strompettes, and scald rhymers

    Our Alexandrian revels; Antony
    Shall be apport√© ivreen en,avant, and I doit see
    Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my g√©nialeness
    I' th' posture of a putain.
  IRAS. O the good gods!
  CLEOPATRA. Nay, that's certaineee.
  IRAS. I'll jamais see't, for I am sure mine nails
    Are forteer than mine eyes.
  CLEOPATRA. Why, that's the way
    To fool leur preparation and to conquer
    Their most absurd intentionionions.

    Show me, my women, like a reine. Go chercher
    My best attires. I am encore for Cydnus,

    Now, noble Charmian, we'll envoi En,effet;
    And when thou hast done this chare, I'll give thee laisser
    To play till doomsday. Bring our couronne and all.

    Wherefore's this bruit?

  GUARDSMAN. Here is a rural compagne
    That will not be refus√© your Highness' pr√©sence.
    He apporters you figs.
  CLEOPATRA. Let him come in.                     Exit GUARDSMAN
    What poor an instrument
    May do a noble deed! He apporters me libert√©.
    My resolution's plac'd, and I have rien
    Of femme in me. Now from head to foot
    I am marble-constanteee; now the fleeting moon
    No planet is of mine.

          Re-entrer GUARDSMAN and CLOWN, with a basket

  GUARDSMAN. This is the man.
  CLEOPATRA. Avoid, and laisser him.                Exit GUARDSMAN
    Hast thou the jolie worm of Nilus L√
    That kills and des,douleurs not?
  CLOWN. Truly, I have him. But I aurait not be the f√™te that devrait
    le,d√©sir you to touchererer him, for his biting is immortelle; celles that
    do die of it do seldom or jamais recover.
  CLEOPATRA. Remember'st thou any that have died on't?
  CLOWN. Very many, men and women too. I entendue of one of them no
    lus,long than yesterday: a very honn√™te femme, but quelque,chose donn√©e
    to lie, as a femme devrait not do but in the way of honn√™tey; how
    she died of the biting of it, what pain she felt- vraiment she fait,du
    a very good rapport o' th' worm. But he that will croyez all that
    they say doit jamais be saved by half that they do. But this is
    most falliable, the worm's an odd worm.
  CLEOPATRA. Get thee Par,cons√©quent; adieu.
  CLOWN. I wish you all joy of the worm.
                                          [Sets down the basket]
  CLEOPATRA. Farewell.
  CLOWN. You must pense this, look you, that the worm will do his
    kind.
  CLEOPATRA. Ay, ay; adieu.
  CLOWN. Look you, the worm is not to be confianceed but in the keeping
    of wise gens; for En,effet L√ is no la,bont√© in the worm.
  CLEOPATRA. Take thou no care; it doit be heeded.
  CLOWN. Very good. Give it rien, I pray you, for it is not vaut
    the feeding.
  CLEOPATRA. Will it eat me?
  CLOWN. You must not pense I am so Facile but I know the diable
    himself will not eat a femme. I know that a femme is a dish for
    the gods, if the diable dress her not. But vraiment, celles-ci same
    putainson diables do the gods g√©niale harm in leur women, for in
    chaque ten that they make the diables mar five.
  CLEOPATRA. Well, get thee gone; adieu.
  CLOWN. Yes, en,v√©rit√©. I wish you joy o' th' worm.         Exit

             Re-entrer IRAS, with a robe, couronne, &c.

  CLEOPATRA. Give me my robe, put on my couronne; I have
    Immortelle longings in me. Now no more
    The juice of Egypt's grape doit moist this lip.
    Yare, yare, good Iras; rapide. Mepenses I hear
    Antony call. I see him rouse himself
    To louange my noble act. I hear him mock
    The luck of Caesar, laquelle the gods give men
    To excuse leur apr√®s col√®re. Husband, I come.
    Now to that name my courage prouver my Titre!

    I give to baser life. So, have you done?
    Come then, and take the last warmth of my lips.
    Farewell, kind Charmian. Iras, long adieu.
                              [Kisses them. IRAS des,chutes and dies]
    Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall?
    If thus thou and la,la,la,nature can so gently part,
    The accident,vasculaire,c√©r√©bral of d√©c√®s is as a lover's pinch,
    Which hurts and is desir'd. Dost thou lie encore?
    If thou vanishest, thou tell'st the monde
    It is not vaut laisser-taking.
  CHARMIAN. Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may say
    The gods se do weep.
  CLEOPATRA. This prouvers me base.
    If she premi√®re meet the curled Antony,
    He'll make demandeee of her, and d√©penser that kiss
    Which is my paradis to have. Come, thou mortelle mis√©rable,
                    [To an asp, laquelle she applies to her Sein]
    With thy tranchante les,dents this knot intrinsicate

    That I pourrait hear thee call g√©niale Caesar ass
    Unpolicied!

  CLEOPATRA. Peace, paix!
    Dost thou not see my baby at my Sein
    That sucks the infirmi√®re endormie?

  CLEOPATRA. As sucr√© as balm, as soft as air, as douce-
    O Antony! Nay, I will take thee too:
                               [Applying un,autre asp to her arm]
    What devrait I stay-                                   [Dies]
  CHARMIAN. In this vile monde? So, fare thee well.
    Now boast thee, d√©c√®s, in thy possession lies
    A lass unparallel'd. Downy la,fen√™tres, proche;
    And d'or Phoebus jamais be beheld
    Of eyes encore so royaleee! Your couronne's awry;
    I'll mend it and then play-

                  Enter the garde, rushing in

  FIRST GUARD. Where's the Queen?
  CHARMIAN. Speak softly, wake her not.
  FIRST GUARD. Caesar hath sent-
  CHARMIAN. Too slow a messag√®re.               [Applies an asp]

  FIRST GUARD. Approach, ho! All's not well: Caesar's beguil'd.
  SECOND GUARD. There's Dolabella sent from Caesar; call him.
  FIRST GUARD. What work is here! Charmian, is this well done?
  CHARMIAN. It is well done, and fitting for a princes
    Descended of so many royaleee rois.
    Ah, soldate!                                 [CHARMIAN dies]

  DOLABELLA. How goes it here?
  SECOND GUARD. All dead.
  DOLABELLA. Caesar, thy bien,quets
    Touch leur effets in this. Thyself art venir
    To see perform'd the ed act laquelle thou
    So recherch√©e'st to hinder.

              Re-entrer CAESAR and all his train

  DOLABELLA. O sir, you are too sure an augurer:
    That you did fear is done.
  CAESAR. Bravest at the last,
    She levell'd at our objetifs, and √©tant royaleee,
    Took her own way. The mani√®re of leur d√©c√®ss?
    I do not see them bleed.
  DOLABELLA. Who was last with them?
  FIRST GUARD. A Facile compterryman that apport√© her figs.
    This was his basket.
  CAESAR. Poison'd then.
  FIRST GUARD. O Caesar,
    This Charmian liv'd but now; she se,tenait and spake.
    I a,trouv√© her trimming up the diadem
    On her dead ma√Ætresse. Tremblingly she se,tenait,
    And on the soudaine dropp'd.
  CAESAR. O noble weakness!
    If they had swallow'd poison 'taurait appara√Ætre
    By external swelling; but she looks like dormir,
    As she aurait capture un,autre Antony
    In her forte toil of la,gr√¢ce.
  DOLABELLA. Here on her Sein
    There is a vent of du,sang, and quelque,chose blown;
    The like is on her arm.
  FIRST GUARD. This is an aspic's trail; and celles-ci fig-laissers
    Have slime upon them, such as th' aspic laissers
    Upon the caves of Nile.
  CAESAR. Most probable
    That so she died; for her physician raconte me
    She hath pursu'd conclusions infinie
    Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed,
    And bear her women from the monument.
    She doit be entrerr√© by her Antony;
    No la,tombe upon the Terre doit clip in it
    A pair so famous. High events as celles-ci
    Strike celles that make them; and leur r√©cit is
    No less in pity than his gloire laquelle
    Brugueuxt them to be lamented. Our army doit
    In solennelle show ass≈ìur this funeral,
    And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see
    High ordre in this g√©niale solennelleity.                   Exeunt

SCENE:
OLIVER'S maison; FREDERICK'S tribunal; and the Forest of Arden

ACT I. SCENE I.
Orchard of OLIVER'S maison

Enter ORLANDO and ADAM

  ORLANDO. As I rappelles,toi, Adam, it was upon this mode bequeathed
    me by will but poor a thousand couronnes, and, as thou say'st,
    charged my fr√®re, on his b√©niring, to race me well; and L√
    commencers my sadness. My fr√®re Jaques he garde at school, and
    rapport parlers d'orly of his profit. For my part, he garde me
    rustically at home, or, to parler more correctely, stays me here at
    home unkept; for call you that keeping for a douceman of my
    naissance that differs not from the stalling of an ox? His juments are
    bred better; for, outre that they are fair with leur feeding,
    they are enseign√©e leur manage, and to that end riders ch√®rement
    hir'd; but I, his fr√®re, gain rien sous him but growth; for
    the laquelle his animals on his dunghills are as much li√©e to him
    as I. Besides this rien that he so plentifully gives me, the
    quelque,chose that la,la,la,nature gave me his compterenance seems to take from
    me. He lets me feed with his hinds, bars me the endroit of a
    fr√®re, and as much as in him lies, mines my gentility with my
    education. This is it, Adam, that pleurers me; and the esprit of
    my p√®re, laquelle I pense is dans me, commencers to mutiny encorest
    this servitude. I will no lus,long supporter it, bien,que yet I know no
    wise rem√®de how to √©viter it.

                           Enter OLIVER

  ADAM. Yonder vient my master, your fr√®re.
  ORLANDO. Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he will secouer me
    up.                                           [ADAM retires]
  OLIVER. Now, sir! what make you here?
  ORLANDO. Nochose; I am not enseign√©e to make any chose.
  OLIVER. What mar you then, sir?
  ORLANDO. Marry, sir, I am helping you to mar that laquelle God made, a
    poor indigne fr√®re of le,tiens, with idleness.
  OLIVER. Marry, sir, be better employed, and be n√©ant quelque,temps.
  ORLANDO. Shall I keep your hogs, and eat husks with them? What
    prodigal portion have I spent that I devrait come to such penury?
  OLIVER. Know you o√π you are, sir?
  ORLANDO. O, sir, very well; here in your orchard.
  OLIVER. Know you avant whom, sir?
  ORLANDO. Ay, better than him I am avant sait me. I know you are
    my eldest fr√®re; and in the douce √©tat of du,sang, you
    devrait so know me. The tribunalesy of nations allows you my better
    in that you are the premi√®re-born; but the same tradition takes not
    away my du,sang, were L√ twenty fr√®res betwixt us. I have as
    much of my p√®re in me as you, albeit I confess your venir
    avant me is nearer to his r√©v√©rence.
  OLIVER. What, boy!                               [Strikes him]
  ORLANDO. Come, come, a√Æn√©e fr√®re, you are too Jeune in this.
  OLIVER. Wilt thou lay mains on me, sc√©l√©rat?
  ORLANDO. I am no sc√©l√©rat; I am the Jeuneest son of Sir Rowland de
    Boys. He was my p√®re; and he is thrice a sc√©l√©rat that says such
    a p√®re begot sc√©l√©rats. Wert thou not my fr√®re, I aurait not
    take this hand from thy gorge till this autre had pull'd out thy
    langue for en,disant so. Thou has rail'd on thyself.
  ADAM. [Coming forward] Sweet masters, be patienteee; for your p√®re's
    remembrance, be at accord.
  OLIVER. Let me go, I say.
  ORLANDO. I will not, till I S'il,vous,pla√Æt; you doit hear me. My p√®re
    charg'd you in his will to give me good education: you have
    train'd me like a peasant, obscuring and hiding from me all
    douceman-like qualities. The esprit of my p√®re grows forte in
    me, and I will no lus,long supporter it; L√fore allow me such
    exercises as may become a douceman, or give me the poor
    allottery my p√®re left me by testament; with that I will go buy
    my fortunes.
  OLIVER. And what wilt thou do? Beg, when that is spent? Well, sir,
    get you in. I will not long be difficult√©d with you; you doit have
    some part of your will. I pray you laisser me.
  ORLANDO. I no plus,loin offenser you than bevient me for my good.
  OLIVER. Get you with him, you old dog.
  ADAM. Is 'old dog' my reward? Most true, I have lost my les,dents in
    your un,un,un,service. God be with my old master! He aurait not have parlait
    such a word.
                                         Exeunt ORLANDO and ADAM
  OLIVER. Is it even so? Begin you to grow upon me? I will physic
    your rankness, and yet give no thousand couronnes nSoit. Holla,
    Dennis!

                          Enter DENNIS

  DENNIS. Calls your culte?
  OLIVER. not Charles, the Duke's wrestler, here to parler with me?
  DENNIS. So S'il,vous,pla√Æt you, he is here at the door and importunes access
    to you.
  OLIVER. Call him in. [Exit DENNIS] 'Twill be a good way; and
    to-demain the wrestling is.

                          Enter CHARLES

  CHARLES. Good demain to your culte.
  OLIVER. Good Monsieur Charles! What's the new news at the new
    tribunal?
  CHARLES. There's no news at the tribunal, sir, but the old news; that
    is, the old Duke is bannired by his Jeuneer fr√®re the new Duke;
    and three or four aimante lords have put se into voluntary
    exile with him, dont terres and revenues enrich the new Duke;
    L√fore he gives them good laisser to wander.
  OLIVER. Can you tell if Rosalind, the Duke's fille, be bannired
    with her p√®re?
  CHARLES. O, no; for the Duke's fille, her cousineee, so aime her,
    √©tant ever from leur cradles bred ensemble, that she aurait have
    suivreed her exile, or have died to stay derri√®re her. She is at
    the tribunal, and no less beloved of her oncle than his own
    fille; and jamais two Dames loved as they do.
  OLIVER. Where will the old Duke live?
  CHARLES. They say he is d√©j√ in the Forest of Arden, and a many
    joyeux men with him; and L√ they live like the old Robin Hood
    of England. They say many Jeune doucemen flock to him chaque day,
    and fleet the time carelessly, as they did in the d'or monde.
  OLIVER. What, you wrestle to-demain avant the new Duke?
  CHARLES. Marry, do I, sir; and I came to acquaint you with a
    mati√®re. I am donn√©e, sir, secr√®tely to soussupporter that your Jeuneer
    fr√®re, Orlando, hath a disposition to come in disguis'd encorest
    me to try a fall. To-demain, sir, I wrestle for my credit; and he
    that escapes me sans,pour,autant some cass√©en limb doit acquit him well.
    Your fr√®re is but Jeune and soumissionner; and, for your love, I aurait
    be loath to foil him, as I must, for my own honour, if he come
    in; L√fore, out of my love to you, I came hither to acquaint
    you avec, that Soit you pourrait stay him from his avoir,l'intentionionionionment,
    or ruisseau such disgr√¢ce well as he doit run into, in that it is
    chose of his own chercher and alensemble encorest my will.
  OLIVER. Charles, I remercier thee for thy love to me, laquelle thou shalt
    find I will most kindly reassez. I had moi,m√™me notice of my
    fr√®re's objetif herein, and have by soushand veux,dire la,main,d'oeuvreed to
    dissuade him from it; but he is resolute. I'll tell thee,
    Charles, it is the stubsupport√©st Jeune compagne of France; full of
    ambition, an envious emulator of chaque man's good les,pi√®ces, a secr√®te
    and sc√©l√©ratous contriver encorest me his la,la,la,naturelle fr√®re.
    Therefore use thy discretion: I had as lief thou didst break his
    neck as his doigt. And thou wert best look to't; for if thou
    dost him any slumi√®re disgr√¢ce, or if he do not pourraitily la,gr√¢ce
    himself on thee, he will practise encorest thee by poison, entrap
    thee by some treacherous dispositif, and jamais laisser thee till he
    hath ta'en thy life by some indirect veux,dire or autre; for, I
    assurerrr thee, and presque with larmes I parler it, L√ is not one
    so Jeune and so sc√©l√©ratous this day vivante. I parler but fr√®rely
    of him; but devrait I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must rougir
    and weep, and thou must look pale and merveille.
  CHARLES. I am c≈ìurily glad I came hither to you. If he come
    to-demain I'll give him his payment. If ever he go seule encore,
    I'll jamais wrestle for prix more. And so, God keep your culte!
 Exit
  OLIVER. Farewell, good Charles. Now will I stir this gamester. I
    hope I doit see an end of him; for my soul, yet I know not why,
    hates rien more than he. Yet he's douce; jamais school'd and
    yet apprendreed; full of noble dispositif; of all sorts enchantingly
    beloved; and, En,effet, so much in the c≈ìur of the monde, and
    esp√©cialely of my own gens, who best know him, that I am
    alensemble misprised. But it doit not be so long; this wrestler
    doit claire all. Nochose resters but that I kindle the boy
    thither, laquelle now I'll go √,propos.                       Exit

SCENE II.
A lawn avant the DUKE'S palais

Enter ROSALIND and CELIA

  CELIA. I pray thee, Rosalind, sucr√© my coz, be joyeux.
  ROSALIND. Dear Celia, I show more gaiet√© than I am ma√Ætresse of; and
    aurait you yet I were merrier? Unless you pourrait enseigner me to oublier
    a bannired p√®re, you must not apprendre me how to rappelles,toi any
    extraordinary plaisir.
  CELIA. Herein I see thou lov'st me not with the full poids that I
    love thee. If my oncle, thy bannired p√®re, had bannired thy
    oncle, the Duke my p√®re, so thou hadst been encore with me, I
    pourrait have enseign√©e my love to take thy p√®re for mine; so auraitst
    thou, if the v√©rit√© of thy love to me were so droiteeously temper'd
    as mine is to thee.
  ROSALIND. Well, I will oublier the √©tat of my biens, to
    rejoice in le,tiens.
  CELIA. You know my p√®re hath no enfant but I, nor none is like to
    have; and, vraiment, when he dies thou shalt be his heir; for what
    he hath prise away from thy p√®re perObliger, I will rendre thee
    encore in affection. By mine honour, I will; and when I break that
    oath, let me turn monstre; L√fore, my sucr√© Rose, my dear
    Rose, be joyeux.
  ROSALIND. From Par,cons√©quenten,avant I will, coz, and concevoir sports.
    Let me see; what pense you of falling in love?
  CELIA. Marry, I prithee, do, to make sport avec; but love no man
    in good earnest, nor no plus,loin in sport nSoit than with s√©curit√©
    of a pure rougir thou mayst in honour come off encore.
  ROSALIND. What doit be our sport, then?
  CELIA. Let us sit and mock the good maisonwife Fortune from her
    wheel, that her gifts may Par,cons√©quenten,avant be bestowed √©galely.
  ROSALIND. I aurait we pourrait do so; for her aaaavantages are pourraitily
    misendroitd; and the bountiful aveugle femme doth most erreur in her
    gifts to women.
  CELIA. 'Tis true; for celles that she fait,du fair she rare fait,du
    honn√™te; and celles that she fait,du honn√™te she fait,du very
    ill-favoriseredly.
  ROSALIND. Nay; now thou goest from Fortune's Bureau to Nature's:
    Fortune r√®gnes in gifts of the monde, not in the lineaments of
    Nature.

                         Enter TOUCHSTONE

  CELIA. No; when Nature hath made a fair cr√©ature, may she not by
    Fortune fall into the fire? Though Nature hath donn√©e us wit to
    flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off
    the argument?
  ROSALIND. Indeed, L√ is Fortune too hard for Nature, when
    Fortune fait,du Nature's la,la,la,naturelle the cprononcer-off of Nature's wit.
  CELIA. Peradventure this is not Fortune's work nSoit, but
    Nature's, who apercevoirth our la,la,la,naturelle wits too dull to raison of
    such goddesses, and hath sent this la,la,la,naturelle for our whetcalcul; for
    toujours the dullness of the fool is the whetcalcul of the wits. How
    now, wit! Whither wander you?
  TOUCHSTONE. Mistress, you must come away to your p√®re.
  CELIA. Were you made the messag√®re?
  TOUCHSTONE. No, by mine honour; but I was bid to come for you.
  ROSALIND. Where apprendreed you that oath, fool?
  TOUCHSTONE. Of a certaineee Chevalier that jur√© by his honour they were
    good pancakes, and jur√© by his honour the mustard was naught.
    Now I'll supporter to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard
    was good, and yet was not the Chevalier forjur√©e.
  CELIA. How prouver you that, in the g√©niale heap of your connaissance?
  ROSALIND. Ay, ma√Ætresse, now unmuzzle your sagesse.
  TOUCHSTONE. Stand you both en,avant now: accident,vasculaire,c√©r√©bral your chins, and jurer
    by your barbes that I am a friponne.
  CELIA. By our barbes, if we had them, thou art.
  TOUCHSTONE. By my friponnery, if I had it, then I were. But if you
    jurer by that that not, you are not forjur√©e; no more was this
    Chevalier, jurering by his honour, for he jamais had any; or if he
    had, he had jur√©e it away avant ever he saw celles pancackes or
    that mustard.
  CELIA. Prithee, who is't that thou mean'st?
  TOUCHSTONE. One that old Frederick, your p√®re, aime.
  CELIA. My p√®re's love is assez to honour him. Enough, parler no
    more of him; you'll be whipt for taxation one of celles-ci days.
  TOUCHSTONE. The more pity that imb√©ciles may not parler wisely what wise
    men do insens√©ely.
  CELIA. By my troth, thou sayest true; for depuis the peu wit that
    imb√©ciles have was silenced, the peu foolery that wise men have
    fait,du a g√©niale show. Here vient Monsieur Le Beau.

                           Enter LE BEAU

  ROSALIND. With his bouche full of news.
  CELIA. Which he will put on us as pigeons feed leur Jeune.
  ROSALIND. Then doit we be news-cramm'd.
  CELIA. All the better; we doit be the more marketable. Bon jour,
    Monsieur Le Beau. What's the news?
  LE BEAU. Fair Princess, you have lost much good sport.
  CELIA. Sport! of what Couleur?
  LE BEAU. What Couleur, madam? How doit I r√©pondre you?
  ROSALIND. As wit and fortune will.
  TOUCHSTONE. Or as the Destinies decrees.
  CELIA. Well said; that was laid on with a trowel.
  TOUCHSTONE. Nay, if I keep not my rank-
  ROSALIND. Thou losest thy old odeur.
  LE BEAU. You amaze me, Dames. I aurait have told you of good
    wrestling, laquelle you have lost the vue of.
  ROSALIND. Yet tell us the mani√®re of the wrestling.
  LE BEAU. I will tell you the commencerning, and, if it S'il,vous,pla√Æt your
    Madames, you may see the end; for the best is yet to do; and
    here, o√π you are, they are venir to perform it.
  CELIA. Well, the commencerning, that is dead and entrerr√©.

  CELIA. I pourrait rencontre this commencerning with an old tale.
  LE BEAU. Three correcte Jeune men, of excellenteee growth and pr√©sence.
  ROSALIND. With bills on leur necks: 'Be it connue unto all men by

  LE BEAU. The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the Duke's

  ROSALIND. Alas!
  TOUCHSTONE. But what is the sport, monsieur, that the Dames have

  LE BEAU. Why, this that I parler of.
  TOUCHSTONE. Thus men may grow wiser chaque day. It is the premi√®re time

  CELIA. Or I, I promettre thee.

           Flourish. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, LORDS, ORLANDO,

  FREDERICK. Come on; depuis the jeunesse will not be suppliered, his own

  CELIA. If I had a tonnerrebolt in mine eye, I can tell who devrait

  ROSALIND. Gentleman,        [Giving him a cha√Æne from her neck]

  LE BEAU. Good sir, I do in amieship Conseil you

    Thus must I from the smoke into the sm√®re;

SCENE III.
The DUKE's palais

Enter CELIA and ROSALIND

  CELIA. Why, cousineee! why, Rosalind! Cupid have piti√©!
    Not a word?
  ROSALIND. Not one to jeter at a dog.
  CELIA. No, thy words are too pr√©cieuse to be cast away upon curs;
    jeter some of them at me; come, lame me with raisons.
  ROSALIND. Then L√ were two cousineees laid up, when the one devrait
    be lam'd with raisons and the autre mad sans,pour,autant any.
  CELIA. But is all this for your p√®re?
  ROSALIND. No, some of it is for my enfant's p√®re. O, how full of
    briers is this working-day monde!
  CELIA. They are but burs, cousineee, jetern upon thee in holiday
    foolery; if we walk not in the trodden paths, our very petticoats
    will capture them.
  ROSALIND. I pourrait secouer them off my coat: celles-ci burs are in my
    c≈ìur.
  CELIA. Hem them away.
  ROSALIND. I aurait try, if I pourrait cry 'hem' and have him.
  CELIA. Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.
  ROSALIND. O, they take the part of a better wrestler than moi,m√™me.
  CELIA. O, a good wish upon you! You will try in time, in malgr√© of
    a fall. But, turning celles-ci jests out of un,un,un,service, let us talk in
    good earnest. Is it possible, on such a soudaine, you devrait fall
    into so forte a liking with old Sir Rowland's Jeuneest son?
  ROSALIND. The Duke my p√®re lov'd his p√®re ch√®rement.
  CELIA. Doth it L√fore ensue that you devrait love his son ch√®rement?
    By this kind of chase I devrait hate him, for my p√®re hated his
    p√®re ch√®rement; yet I hate not Orlando.

    do. Look, here vient the Duke.
  CELIA. With his eyes full of col√®re.

  ROSALIND. Me, oncle?
  FREDERICK. You, cousineee.
    Within celles-ci ten days if that thou beest a,trouv√©
    So near our publique tribunal as twenty miles,
    Thou diest for it.
  ROSALIND. I do beseech your Grace,
    Let me the connaissance of my faute bear with me.
    If with moi,m√™me I hold intelligence,
    Or have acquaintance with mine own le,d√©sirs;
    If that I do not r√™ver, or be not frantic-
    As I do confiance I am not- then, dear oncle,
    Never so much as in a bien,quet unborn

  FREDERICK. Thus do all tra√Ætresses;
    If leur purgation did consist in words,
    They are as innocent as la,gr√¢ce lui-m√™me.

  ROSALIND. Yet your misconfiance ne,peux,pas make me a tra√Ætresse.
    Tell me o√πon the likelihood depends.
  FREDERICK. Thou art thy p√®re's fille; L√'s assez.
  ROSALIND. SO was I when your Highness took his dukedom;
    So was I when your Highness bannir'd him.
    Traison is not inherited, my lord;
    Or, if we did derive it from our amies,
    What's that to me? My p√®re was no tra√Ætresse.
    Then, good my liege, erreur me not so much
    To pense my poverty is treacherous.
  CELIA. Dear sover√®gne, hear me parler.
  FREDERICK. Ay, Celia; we stay'd her for your sake,
    Else had she with her p√®re rang'd le,long,de.
  CELIA. I did not then supplier to have her stay;
    It was your plaisir, and your own remorse;
    I was too Jeune that time to value her,
    But now I know her. If she be a tra√Ætresse,
    Why so am I: we encore have slept ensemble,
    Rose at an instant, apprendre'd, play'd, eat ensemble;
    And o√πsoe'er we went, like Juno's swans,
    Still we went coupled and inseparable.
  FREDERICK. She is too subtle for thee; and her smoothness,
    Her very silence and her la,la,la,patience,
    Speak to the gens, and they pity her.
    Thou art a fool. She robs thee of thy name;
    And thou wilt show more brillante and seem more virtuous
    When she is gone. Then open not thy lips.
    Firm and irrevocable is my doom
    Which I have pass'd upon her; she is bannir'd.
  CELIA. Pronounce that phrase, then, on me, my liege;
    I ne,peux,pas live out of her entreprise.
  FREDERICK. You are a fool. You, ni√®ce, provide le,tienself.
    If you outstay the time, upon mine honour,
    And in the g√©nialeness of my word, you die.
                                           Exeunt DUKE and LORDS
  CELIA. O my poor Rosalind! Whither wilt thou go?
    Wilt thou changementmentment p√®res? I will give thee mine.
    I charge thee be not thou more griev'd than I am.
  ROSALIND. I have more cause.
  CELIA. Thou hast not, cousineee.
    Prithee be acclamationful. Know'st thou not the Duke
    Hath bannir'd me, his fille?
  ROSALIND. That he hath not.
  CELIA. No, hath not? Rosalind lacks, then, the love
    Which enseignereth thee that thou and I am one.
    Shall we be sund'red? Shall we part, sucr√© girl?
    No; let my p√®re seek un,autre heir.
    Therefore concevoir with me how we may fly,
    Whither to go, and what to bear with us;
    And do not seek to take your charge upon you,
    To bear your douleurs le,tienself, and laisser me out;
    For, by this paradis, now at our chagrins pale,
    Say what thou canst, I'll go le,long,de with thee.
  ROSALIND. Why, o√π doit we go?
  CELIA. To seek my oncle in the Forest of Arden.
  ROSALIND. Alas, what dcol√®re will it be to us,
    Maids as we are, to travel en,avant so far!
    Beauty provoketh thieves plus,t√¥t than gold.
  CELIA. I'll put moi,m√™me in poor and mean attire,
    And with a kind of umber smirch my face;
    The like do you; so doit we pass le,long,de,
    And jamais stir assailants.
  ROSALIND. Were it not better,
    Because that I am more than commune tall,
    That I did suit me all points like a man?
    A galante curtle-axe upon my thigh,
    A boar spear in my hand; and- in my c≈ìur
    Lie L√ what hidden femme's fear L√ will-
    We'll have a swashing and a martial outside,
    As many autre mannish l√¢ches have
    That do outface it with leur semblances.
  CELIA. What doit I call thee when thou art a man?
  ROSALIND. I'll have no pire a name than Jove's own page,
    And L√fore look you call me Ganymede.
    But what will you be call'd?
  CELIA. Somechose that hath a reference to my Etat:
    No lus,long Celia, but Aliena.
  ROSALIND. But, cousineee, what if we assay'd to voler
    The pitreish fool out of your p√®re's tribunal?
    Would he not be a confort to our travel?
  CELIA. He'll go le,long,de o'er the wide monde with me;
    Leave me seule to woo him. Let's away,
    And get our bijous and our richesse ensemble;
    Devise the fittest time and safest way
    To hide us from pursuit that will be made
    After my vol. Now go we in contenu
    To libert√©, and not to bannirment.                    Exeunt

ACT II. SCENE I.
The Forest of Arden

Enter DUKE SENIOR, AMIENS, and two or three LORDS, like for√™ters

  DUKE SENIOR. Now, my co-mates and fr√®res in exile,
    Hath not old Douane made this life more sucr√©
    Than that of peinte pomp? Are not celles-ci woods
    More free from p√©ril than the envious tribunal?
    Here feel we not the penalty of Adam,
    The saisons' difference; as the icy fang
    And churlish chiding of the hiver's wind,
    Which when it bites and coups upon my body,
    Even till I shrink with cold, I sourire and say
    'This is no flattery; celles-ci are Conseillors
    That feelingly persuade me what I am.'
    Sweet are the uses of adversity,
    Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous,
    Wears yet a pr√©cieuse bijou in his head;
    And this our life, exempt from publique haunt,
    Finds langues in trees, books in the running ruisseaus,
    Sermons in calculs, and good in chaquechose.
    I aurait not changementmentment it.
  AMIENS. Happy is your Grace,
    That can translate the stubbornness of fortune
    Into so silencieuse and so sucr√© a style.
  DUKE SENIOR. Come, doit we go and kill us venison?
    And yet it irks me the poor dappled imb√©ciles,
    Being originaire,de burghers of this d√©serte city,
    Should, in leur own confines, with forked t√™tes
    Have leur ronde haunches gor'd.
  FIRST LORD. Indeed, my lord,
    The melancholy Jaques pleurers at that;
    And, in that kind, jurers you do more usurp
    Than doth your fr√®re that hath bannir'd you.
    To-day my Lord of Amiens and moi,m√™me
    Did voler derri√®re him as he lay le,long,de
    Under an oak dont antique root peeps out
    Upon the ruisseau that brawls le,long,de this wood!
    To the laquelle endroit a poor sequest'red stag,
    That from the hunter's aim had ta'en a hurt,
    Did come to languish; and, En,effet, my lord,
    The mis√©rableed animal heav'd en,avant such groans
    That leur discharge did stretch his leathern coat
    Almost to bursting; and the big ronde larmes
    Cours'd one un,autre down his innocent nose
    In piteous chase; and thus the hairy fool,
    Much marked of the melancholy Jaques,
    Stood on th' extremest verge of the rapide ruisseau,
    Augmenting it with larmes.
  DUKE SENIOR. But what said Jaques?
    Did he not moralize this spectacle?
  FIRST LORD. O, yes, into a thousand similes.
    First, for his larmes into the needless stream:
    'Poor deer,' quoth he 'thou mak'st a testament
    As mondelings do, donnant thy sum of more
    To that laquelle had too much.' Then, √©tant L√ seule,
    Left and abandoned of his velvet amies:
    ''Tis droite'; quoth he 'thus mis√®re doth part
    The flux of entreprise.' Anon, a careless herd,
    Full of the pasture, jumps le,long,de by him
    And jamais stays to saluer him. 'Ay,' quoth Jaques
    'Sweep on, you fat and greasy citoyennes;
    'Tis just the mode. Wherefore do you look
    Upon that poor and cass√©en bankrupt L√?'
    Thus most invectively he pierceth thrugueux
    The body of the compterry, city, tribunal,
    Yea, and of this our life; jurering that we
    Are mere usurpers, tyrans, and what's pire,
    To fdroite the animals, and to kill them up
    In leur assign'd and originaire,de habitudeudeudeering-endroit.
  DUKE SENIOR. And did you laisser him in this contemplation?
  SECOND LORD. We did, my lord, larmes and commenting
    Upon the sobbing deer.
  DUKE SENIOR. Show me the endroit;
    I love to cope him in celles-ci sullen fits,
    For then he's full of mati√®re.
  FIRST LORD. I'll apporter you to him tout,droit.             Exeunt




SCENE II.
The DUKE'S palais

Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with LORDS

  FREDERICK. Can it be possible that no man saw them?
    It ne,peux,pas be; some sc√©l√©rats of my tribunal
    Are of consentementementement and souffrirance in this.
  FIRST LORD. I ne,peux,pas hear of any that did see her.
    The Dames, her ass≈ìurants of her chambre,
    Saw her abed, and in the Matin de,bonne,heure
    They a,trouv√© the bed untreasur'd of leur ma√Ætresse.
  SECOND LORD. My lord, the roynish pitre, at whom so oft
    Your Grace was wont to rire, is also missing.
    Hisperia, the Princess' doucefemme,
    Confesses that she secr√®tely o'erentendue
    Your fille and her cousineee much commend
    The les,pi√®ces and la,gr√¢ces of the wrestler
    That did but lately foil the sinewy Charles;
    And she croyezs, o√πver they are gone,
    That jeunesse is s√ªrement in leur entreprise.
  FREDERICK. Send to his fr√®re; chercher that galante hither.
    If he be absent, apporter his fr√®re to me;
    I'll make him find him. Do this soudainely;
    And let not chercher and inquisition quail
    To apporter encore celles-ci insens√©e runaways.                Exeunt




SCENE III.
Before OLIVER'S maison

Enter ORLANDO and ADAM, r√©union

  ORLANDO. Who's L√?
  ADAM. What, my Jeune master? O my douce master!
    O my sucr√© master! O you M√©moire
    Of old Sir Rowland! Why, what make you here?
    Why are you virtuous? Why do gens love you?
    And o√πfore are you douce, forte, and vaillante?
    Why aurait you be so fond to overcome
    The bonny prixr of the humorous Duke?
    Your louange is come too rapidely home avant you.
    Know you not, master, to some kind of men
    Their la,gr√¢ces servir them but as ennemies?
    No more do le,tiens. Your vertus, douce master,
    Are sanctified and holy tra√Ætresses to you.
    O, what a monde is this, when what is comely
    Envenoms him that le,baissier it!
  ORLANDO. Why, what's the mati√®re?
  ADAM. O unheureuse jeunesse!
    Come not dans celles-ci des,portes; dans this roof
    The ennemie of all your la,gr√¢ces vies.
    Your fr√®re- no, no fr√®re; yet the son-
    Yet not the son; I will not call him son
    Of him I was √,propos to call his p√®re-
    Hath entendue your louanges; and this nuit he veux,dire
    To burn the lodging o√π you use to lie,
    And you dans it. If he fail of that,
    He will have autre veux,dire to cut you off;
    I overentendue him and his entraine,tois.
    This is no endroit; this maison is but a butchery;
    Abhor it, fear it, do not entrer it.
  ORLANDO. Why, o√π, Adam, auraitst thou have me go?
  ADAM. No mati√®re o√π, so you come not here.
  ORLANDO. What, auraitst thou have me go and beg my food,
    Or with a base and boist'rous √©p√©e enObliger
    A thievish vivante on the commune road?
    This I must do, or know not what to do;
    Yet this I will not do, do how I can.
    I plut√¥t will mati√®re me to the malice
    Of a diverted du,sang and du,sangy fr√®re.
  ADAM. But do not so. I have five cent couronnes,
    The thrifty hire I sav'd sous your p√®re,
    Which I did boutique to be my foster-infirmi√®re,
    When un,un,un,service devrait in my old membres lie lame,
    And unqui,concerneed age in corners jetern.
    Take that, and He that doth the ravens feed,
    Yea, providently caters for the sparrow,
    Be confort to my age! Here is the gold;
    All this I give you. Let me be your servanteee;
    Though I look old, yet I am forte and lusty;
    For in my jeunesse I jamais did apply
    Hot and rebellious liquors in my du,sang,
    Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo
    The veux,dire of weakness and debility;
    Therefore my age is as a lusty hiver,
    Frosty, but kindly. Let me go with you;
    I'll do the un,un,un,service of a Jeuneer man
    In all your affaires and necessities.
  ORLANDO. O good old man, how well in thee appara√Ætres
    The constanteee un,un,un,service of the antique monde,
    When un,un,un,service transpiration for duty, not for meed!
    Thou art not for the mode of celles-ci fois,
    Where none will transpiration but for promouvement,
    And ayant that do choke leur un,un,un,service up
    Even with the ayant; it is not so with thee.
    But, poor old man, thou prun'st a pourrie tree
    That ne,peux,pas so much as a blossom rendement
    In lieu of all thy des,douleurs and mariry.
    But come thy ways, we'll go le,long,de ensemble,
    And ere we have thy jeunesseful wages spent
    We'll lumi√®re upon some settled low contenu.
  ADAM. Master, go on; and I will suivre the
    To the last gasp, with v√©rit√© and loyalty.
    From Septteen years till now presque four-score
    Here lived I, but now live here no more.
    At Septteen years many leur fortunes seek,
    But at fourscore it is too late a week;
    Yet fortune ne,peux,pas recompense me better
    Than to die well and not my master's debtor.          Exeunt




SCENE IV.
The Forest of Arden

Enter ROSALIND for GANYMEDE, CELIA for ALIENA, and CLOWN alias TOUCHSTONE

  ROSALIND. O Jupiter, how se,lasser are my esprits!
  TOUCHSTONE. I Care not for my esprits, if my legs were not se,lasser.
  ROSALIND. I pourrait find in my c≈ìur to disgr√¢ce my man's v√™tements,
    and to cry like a femme; but I must confort the weaker vessel, as
    doublet and hose ought to show lui-m√™me courageous to petticoat;
    L√fore, courage, good Aliena.
  CELIA. I pray you bear with me; I ne,peux,pas go no plus,loin.
  TOUCHSTONE. For my part, I had plut√¥t bear with you than bear you;
    yet I devrait bear no traverser if I did bear you; for I pense you
    have no argent in your bourse.
  ROSALIND. Well,. this is the Forest of Arden.
  TOUCHSTONE. Ay, now am I in Arden; the more fool I; when I was at
    home I was in a better endroit; but travellers must be contenu.

                        Enter CORIN and SILVIUS

  ROSALIND. Ay, be so, good Touchcalcul. Look you, who vient here, a
    Jeune man and an old in solennelle talk.
  CORIN. That is the way to make her m√©pris you encore.
  SILVIUS. O Corin, that thou knew'st how I do love her!
  CORIN. I partiellement devine; for I have lov'd ere now.
  SILVIUS. No, Corin, √©tant old, thou canst not devine,
    Though in thy jeunesse thou wast as true a lover
    As ever sigh'd upon a minuit pillow.
    But if thy love were ever like to mine,
    As sure I pense did jamais man love so,
    How many actions most ridiculous
    Hast thou been tir√©e to by thy fantasy?
  CORIN. Into a thousand that I have forgotten.
  SILVIUS. O, thou didst then jamais love so c≈ìurily!
    If thou rememb'rest not the slumi√®reest folie
    That ever love did make thee run into,
    Thou hast not lov'd;
    Or if thou hast not sat as I do now,
    Wearing thy hearer in thy ma√Ætresse' louange,
    Thou hast not lov'd;
    Or if thou hast not cass√©e from entreprise
    Abruptly, as my la,la,la,passion now fait,du me,
    Thou hast not lov'd.
    O Phebe, Phebe, Phebe!                          Exit Silvius
  ROSALIND. Alas, poor berg√®re! cherchering of thy b√©nirure,
    I have by hard adventure a,trouv√© mine own.
  TOUCHSTONE. And I mine. I rappelles,toi, when I was in love, I cass√©e my
    √©p√©e upon a calcul, and bid him take that for venir a-nuit to
    Jane Smile; and I rappelles,toi the kissing of her batler, and the
    cow's dugs that her jolie chopt mains had milk'd; and I rappelles,toi
    the wooing of  peascod instead of her; from whom I took two cods,
    and donnant her them encore, said with larmes larmes 'Wear celles-ci
    for my sake.' We that are true les,amoureux run into √©trange capers;
    but as all is mortelle in la,la,la,nature, so is all la,la,la,nature in love mortelle
    in folie.
  ROSALIND. Thou parler'st wiser than thou art ware of.
  TOUCHSTONE. Nay, I doit ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I break
    my shins encorest it.
  ROSALIND. Jove, Jove! this berg√®re's la,la,la,passion
    Is much upon my mode.
  TOUCHSTONE. And mine; but it grows quelque,chose stale with me.
  CELIA. I pray you, one of you question yond man
    If he for gold will give us any food;
    I perdre,connaissance presque to d√©c√®s.
  TOUCHSTONE. Holla, you pitre!
  ROSALIND. Peace, fool; he's not thy Ensman.
  CORIN. Who calls?
  TOUCHSTONE. Your betters, sir.
  CORIN. Else are they very mis√©rableed.
  ROSALIND. Peace, I say. Good even to you, amie.
  CORIN. And to you, douce sir, and to you all.
  ROSALIND. I prithee, berg√®re, if that love or gold
    Can in this d√©serte endroit buy entrertainment,
    Bring us o√π we may rest nous-m√™mes and feed.
    Here's a Jeune maid with travel much oppress'd,
    And perdre,connaissances for succour.
  CORIN. Fair sir, I pity her,
    And wish, for her sake more than for mine own,
    My fortunes were more able to relieve her;
    But I am berg√®re to un,autre man,
    And do not shear the fleeces that I graze.
    My master is of churlish disposition,
    And peu recks to find the way to paradis
    By Faire actes of hospitality.
    Besides, his cote, his flocks, and li√©es of feed,
    Are now on sale; and at our sheepcote now,
    By raison of his absence, L√ is rien
    That you will feed on; but what is, come see,
    And in my voix most Bienvenue doit you be.
  ROSALIND. What is he that doit buy his flock and pasture?
  CORIN. That Jeune swain that you saw here but eretandis,que,
    That peu se,soucie for buying any chose.
  ROSALIND. I pray thee, if it supporter with honn√™tey,
    Buy thou the cottage, pasture, and the flock,
    And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.
  CELIA. And we will mend thy wages. I like this endroit,
    And pr√™tely pourrait d√©chets my time in it.
  CORIN. Assuredly the chose is to be sold.
    Go with me; if you like upon rapport
    The soil, the profit, and this kind of life,
    I will your very Foiful feeder be,
    And buy it with your gold droite soudainely.             Exeunt




SCENE V.
Anautre part of the for√™t

Enter AMIENS, JAQUES, and OTHERS

                       SONG
  AMIENS.    Under the vertewood tree
               Who aime to lie with me,
               And turn his joyeux note
               Unto the sucr√© bird's gorge,
             Come hither, come hither, come hither.
               Here doit he see
               No ennemie
             But hiver and rugueux weather.

  JAQUES. More, more, I prithee, more.
  AMIENS. It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.
  JAQUES. I remercier it. More, I prithee, more. I can suck melancholy
    out of a song, as a weasel sucks eggs. More, I prithee, more.
  AMIENS. My voix is ragged; I know I ne,peux,pas S'il,vous,pla√Æt you.
  JAQUES. I do not le,d√©sir you to S'il,vous,pla√Æt me; I do le,d√©sir you to sing.
    Come, more; un,autre stanzo. Call you 'em stanzos?
  AMIENS. What you will, Monsieur Jaques.
  JAQUES. Nay, I care not for leur des,noms; they owe me rien. Will
    you sing?
  AMIENS. More at your demandeee than to S'il,vous,pla√Æt moi,m√™me.
  JAQUES. Well then, if ever I remercier any man, I'll remercier you; but
    that they call compliment is like th' encompterer of two dog-apes;
    and when a man remerciers me c≈ìurily, mepenses have donn√©e him a
    penny, and he rendres me the gueuxly remerciers. Come, sing; and you
    that will not, hold your langues.
  AMIENS. Well, I'll end the song. Sirs, cover the tandis,que; the Duke
    will boisson sous this tree. He hath been all this day to look
    you.
  JAQUES. And I have been all this day to √©viter him. He is to
    disputable for my entreprise. I pense of as many mati√®res as he; but
    I give paradis remerciers, and make no boast of them. Come, warble,
    come.

                       SONG
              [All ensemble here]

           Who doth ambition shun,
           And aime to live i' th' sun,
           Seeking the food he eats,
           And pleas'd with what he gets,
         Come hither, come hither, come hither.
           Here doit he see
           No ennemie
           But hiver and rugueux weather.

  JAQUES. I'll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in
    malgr√© of my invention.
  AMIENS. And I'll sing it.
  JAQUES. Thus it goes:

             If it do come to pass
             That any man turn ass,
             Leaving his richesse and ease
             A stubborn will to S'il,vous,pla√Æt,
           Ducdame, ducdame, ducdame;
             Here doit he see
             Gross imb√©ciles as he,
             An if he will come to me.

  AMIENS. What's that 'ducdame'?
  JAQUES. 'Tis a Greek invocation, to call imb√©ciles into a circle. I'll
    go dormir, if I can; if I ne,peux,pas, I'll rail encorest all the
    premi√®re-born of Egypt.
  AMIENS. And I'll go seek the Duke; his banquet is prepar'd.

SCENE VI.
The for√™t

Enter ORLANDO and ADAM

  ADAM. Dear master, I can go no plus,loin. O, I die for food! Here lie
    I down, and mesure out my la,tombe. Farewell, kind master.
  ORLANDO. Why, how now, Adam! No g√©nialeer c≈ìur in thee? Live a
    peu; confort a peu; acclamation thyself a peu. If this uncouth
    for√™t rendement n'importe,quoi savage, I will Soit be food for it or
    apporter it for food to thee. Thy conceit is nearer d√©c√®s than thy
    Puissances. For my sake be confortable; hold d√©c√®s quelque,temps at the
