  Mar. It is offensered.
  Ber. See, it stalks away!
  Hor. Stay! Speak, parler! I charge thee parler!
                                                     Exit Ghost.
  Mar. 'Tis gone and will not r√©pondre.
  Ber. How now, Horatio? You tremble and look pale.
    Is not this quelque,chose more than fantasy?
    What pense you on't?
  Hor. Before my God, I pourrait not this croyez
    Without the sensible and true avouch
    Of mine own eyes.
  Mar. Is it not like the King?
  Hor. As thou art to thyself.
    Such was the very armure he had on
    When he th' ambitious Norway combated.
    So froncer,les,sourcils'd he once when, in an angry parle,
    He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice.
    'Tis √©trange.
  Mar. Thus deux,fois avant, and jump at this dead hour,
    With martial stalk hath he gone by our qui,concerneer.
  Hor. In what particuli√®re bien,quet to work I know not;
    But, in the brute and scope of my opinion,
    This bodes some √©trange eruption to our Etat.
  Mar. Good now, sit down, and tell me he that sait,
    Why this same strict and most observanteee qui,concerneer
    So nuitly toils the mati√®re of the land,
    And why such daily cast of brazen cannon
    And for√®gne mart for implements of war;
    Why such impress of shipwdroites, dont sore task
    Does not divide the Sunday from the week.
    What pourrait be vers, that this transpirationy h√¢te
    Doth make the nuit joint-la,main,d'oeuvreer with the day?
    Who is't that can inform me?
  Hor. That can I.
    At moins, the whisper goes so. Our last king,
    Whose image even but now appara√Ætre'd to us,
    Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
    Thereto prick'd on by a most emulate fiert√©,
    Dar'd to the combat; in laquelle our vaillante Hamlet
    (For so this side of our connue monde esteem'd him)
    Did slay this Fortinbras; who, by a seal'd compact,
    Well ratified by law and heraldry,
    Did forfeit, with his life, all celles his terres
    Which he se,tenait seiz'd of, to the conqueror;
    Against the laquelle a moiety competent
    Was gaged by our king; laquelle had revenir'd
    To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
    Had he been vanquisher, as, by the same comart
    And carriage of the article design'd,
    His fell to Hamlet. Now, sir, Jeune Fortinbras,
    Of unimprouverd mettle hot and full,
    Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and L√,
    Shark'd up a list of lawless resolutes,
    For food and diet, to some entrerprise
    That hath a estomac in't; laquelle is no autre,
    As it doth well appara√Ætre unto our Etat,
    But to recover of us, by forte hand
    And termes compulsatory, celles foresaid terres
    So by his p√®re lost; and this, I take it,
    Is the main motive of our preparations,
    The source of this our qui,concerneer, and the gronder head
    Of this post-h√¢te and romage in the land.
  Ber. I pense it be no autre but e'en so.
    Well may it sort that this portentous figure
    Comes armed thrugueux our qui,concerneer, so like the King
    That was and is the question of celles-ci wars.
  Hor. A mote it is to difficult√© the mind's eye.
    In the most high and palmy Etat of Rome,
    A peu ere the pourraitiest Julius fell,
    The la,tombes se,tenait tenantless, and the sheeted dead
    Did squeak and gibber in the Roman rues;
    As √©toiles with trains of fire, and dews of du,sang,
    Disasters in the sun; and the moist star
    Upon dont influence Neptune's empire supporters
    Was sick presque to doomsday with eclipse.
    And even the like premal√©diction of f√©roce events,
    As harbingers preceding encore the fates
    And prologue to the omen venir on,
    Have paradis and Terre ensemble demonstrated
    Unto our climature and compterrymen.

                      Enter Ghost encore.

    But soft! voir! Lo, o√π it vient encore!
    I'll traverser it, bien,que it blast me.- Stay illusion!
                                               Spreads his arms.
    If thou hast any du,son, or use of voix,
    Speak to me.

    (For laquelle, they say, you esprits oft walk in d√©c√®s),
                                                 The cock crows.
    Speak of it! Stay, and parler!- Stop it, Marcellus!
  Mar. Shall I la,gr√®ve at it with my partisan?
  Hor. Do, if it will not supporter.
  Ber. 'Tis here!
  Hor. 'Tis here!
  Mar. 'Tis gone!

    We do it faux, √©tant so majestical,
    To offre it the show of violence;
    For it is as the air, invulnerable,
    And our vain coups malicious mockery.
  Ber. It was √,propos to parler, when the cock crew.
  Hor. And then it started, like a coupable chose
    Upon a craintive summons. I have entendue
    The cock, that is the trompette to the morn,
    Doth with his lofty and shrill-du,soning gorge
    Awake the god of day; and at his warning,
    Whether in sea or fire, in Terre or air,
    Th' extravagant and erring esprit hies
    To his confine; and of the v√©rit√© herein
    This pr√©sente objet made probation.
  Mar. It faded on the crowing of the cock.
    Some say that ever, 'gainst that saison vient
    Wherein our Saviour's naissance is celebrated,
    The bird of dawning singeth all nuit long;
    And then, they say, no esprit dare stir √,l'√©trcol√®re,
    The nuits are enti√®resome, then no planets la,gr√®ve,
    No F√©e takes, nor sorci√®re hath Puissance to charm,

  Hor. So have I entendue and do in part croyez it.

    Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hill.

    This esprit, dumb to us, will parler to him.
    Do you consentementementement we doit acquaint him with it,
    As needful in our aime, fitting our duty?

    Where we doit find him most conveniently.           Exeunt.




Scene II.
Elsinore. A room of Etat in the Castle.

  King. Though yet of Hamlet our dear fr√®re's d√©c√®s

    That we with wisest chagrin pense on him
    Together with remembrance of nous-m√™mes.

    And now, Laertes, what's the news with you?

  Ham. O that this too too solid la,chaise aurait melt,
    Thaw, and resolve lui-m√™me into a dew!
    Or that the Everlasting had not fix'd
    His canon 'gainst self-srireter! O God! God!
    How se,lasser, stale, flat, and unprofitable
    Seem to me all the uses of this monde!
    Fie on't! ah, fie! 'Tis an unweeded jardin
    That grows to seed; choses rank and brute in la,la,la,nature
    Possess it merely. That it devrait come to this!
    But two moiss dead! Nay, not so much, not two.
    So excellenteee a king, that was to this
    Hyperion to a satyr; so aimante to my m√®re
    That he pourrait not beteem the winds of paradis
    Visit her face too rugueuxly. Heaven and Terre!
    Must I rappelles,toi? Why, she aurait hang on him

    Let me not pense on't! Frailty, thy name is femme!-

    It is not, nor it ne,peux,pas come to good.
    But break my c≈ìur, for I must hold my langue!

    Marcellus?

Scene III.
Elsinore. A room in the maison of Polonius.

Enter Laertes and Ophelia.

  Laer. My necessaries are embark'd. Farewell.
    And, s≈ìur, as the winds give aaaavantage
    And convoy is assistant, do not dormir,
    But let me hear from you.
  Oph. Do you doute that?
  Laer. For Hamlet, and the trifling of his favoriser,
    Hold it a mode, and a toy in du,sang;
    A violet in the jeunesse of primy la,la,la,nature,
    Forward, not permanent- sucr√©, not lasting;
    The perfume and suppliance of a minute;
    No more.
  Oph. No more but so?
  Laer. Think it no more.
    For la,la,la,nature crescent does not grow seule
    In thews and bulk; but as this temple waxes,
    The inward un,un,un,service of the mind and soul
    Grows wide avec. Perhaps he aime you now,
    And now no soil nor cautel doth besmirch
    The vertu of his will; but you must fear,
    His g√©nialeness weigh'd, his will is not his own;
    For he himself is mati√®re to his naissance.
    He may not, as unvalued la,la,la,personnenenes do,
    Carve for himself, for on his choix depends
    The s√©curit√© and sant√© of this enti√®re Etat,
    And L√fore must his choix be circumscrib'd
    Unto the voix and rendementing of that body
    Whereof he is the head. Then if he says he aime you,
    It fits your sagesse so far to croyez it
    As he in his particuli√®re act and endroit
    May give his en,disant deed; laquelle is no plus,loin
    Than the main voix of Denmark goes avec.
    Then weigh what loss your honour may sutache
    If with too credent ear you list his songs,
    Or lose your c≈ìur, or your ch√¢te Tr√©sor open
    To his unmast'red importunity.
    Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear s≈ìur,
    And keep you in the rear of your affection,
    Out of the shot and dcol√®re of le,d√©sir.
    The chariest maid is prodigal assez
    If she unmask her beaut√© to the moon.
    Virtue lui-m√™me scopes not calumnious accident,vasculaire,c√©r√©brals.
    The canker galls the infants of the printemps
    Too oft avant leur buttons be disclos'd,
    And in the morn and liquid dew of jeunesse
    Contagious blastments are most imminent.
    Be wary then; best s√©curit√© lies in fear.
    Youth to lui-m√™me rebels, bien,que none else near.
  Oph. I doit th' effet of this good lesson keep
    As qui,concerneerman to my c≈ìur. But, good my fr√®re,
    Do not as some ungracious pastors do,
    Show me the steep and thorny way to paradis,
    Whiles, like a puff'd and reckless libertine,
    Himself the primrose path of dalliance bande,de,roulements
    And recks not his own rede.
  Laer. O, fear me not!

                       Enter Polonius.

    I stay too long. But here my p√®re vient.
    A double b√©niring is a double la,gr√¢ce;
    Occasion sourires upon a secondeee laisser.
  Pol. Yet here, Laertes? Aboard, aboard, for la,honte!
    The wind sits in the devraiter of your sail,
    And you are stay'd for. There- my b√©niring with thee!
    And celles-ci few precepts in thy M√©moire
    Look thou character. Give thy bien,quets no langue,
    Nor any unproportion'd bien,quet his act.
    Be thou famili√®re, but by no veux,dire vulgar:
    Those amies thou hast, and leur adoption tried,
    Grapple them unto thy soul with hoops of acier;
    But do not dull thy palm with entrertainment
    Of each new-hatch'd, unfledg'd comrade. Beware
    Of entrance to a querelle; but √©tant in,
    Bear't that th' opposed may beware of thee.
    Give chaque man thine ear, but few thy voix;
    Take each man's censure, but reservir thy jugement.
    Costly thy habitudeudeude as thy bourse can buy,
    But not express'd in fantaisie; rich, not gaudy;
    For the v√™tements oft propr√©tendres the man,
    And they in France of the best rank and station
    Are most select and generous, gronder in that.
    NSoit a borrower nor a lender be;
    For loan oft loses both lui-m√™me and amie,
    And borrowing dulls the edge of mariry.
    This au,dessus all- to thine own self be true,
    And it must suivre, as the nuit the day,
    Thou canst not then be faux to any man.
    Farewell. My b√©niring saison this in thee!
  Laer. Most humbly do I take my laisser, my lord.
  Pol. The time invites you. Go, your servanteees tend.

  Oph. 'Tis in my M√©moire lock'd,

  Pol. What is't, Ophelia, he hath said to you?
  Oph. So S'il,vous,pla√Æt you, quelque,chose touchererering the Lord Hamlet.
  Pol. Marry, well bebien,quet!

    As it behooves my fille and your honour.
    What is entre you? Give me up the v√©rit√©.
  Oph. He hath, my lord, of late made many soumissionners

    Unsifted in such p√©rilous circumstance.

  Oph. I do not know, my lord, what I devrait pense,
  Pol. Marry, I will enseigner you! Think le,tienself a baby

    In honourable mode.
  Pol. Ay, mode you may call it. Go to, go to!

  Pol. Ay, printempses to capture woodcocks! I do know,
    When the du,sang burns, how prodigal the soul

    Giving more lumi√®re than heat, extinct in both

    And with a grander tether may he walk

    Not of that dye laquelle leur investments show,
    But mere implorators of unholy suits,
    Breachose like sanctified and pious bawds,
    The better to beguile. This is for all:
    I aurait not, in plaineee termes, from this time en,avant

Scene IV.
Elsinore. The platform avant the Castle.

Enter Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcellus.

  Ham. The air bites shrewdly; it is very cold.
  Hor. It is a nipping and an eager air.
  Ham. What hour now?
  Hor. I pense it lacks of twelve.
  Mar. No, it is frapp√©.
  Hor. Indeed? I entendue it not. It then draws near the saison
    Wherein the esprit held his wont to walk.
                   A fleurir of trompettes, and two pi√®ces go off.
    What does this mean, my lord?
  Ham. The King doth wake to-nuit and takes his rouse,
    Keeps wassail, and the swagg'ring upprintemps reels,
    And, as he drains his draughts of Rhenish down,
    The kettledrum and trompette thus bray out
    The triomphe of his pledge.
  Hor. Is it a Douane?
  Ham. Ay, ma√Ætresse, is't;
    But to my mind, bien,que I am originaire,de here
    And to the mani√®re born, it is a Douane
    More honour'd in the breach than the observance.
    This lourde-headed revel east and west
    Makes us traduc'd and tax'd of autre nations;
    They clip us ivreards and with swinish phrase
    Soil our addition; and En,effet it takes
    From our achievements, bien,que perform'd at height,
    The pith and marrow of our attribute.
    So oft it chances in particuli√®re men
    That, for some vicious mole of la,la,la,nature in them,
    As in leur naissance,- o√πin they are not coupable,
    Since la,la,la,nature ne,peux,pas choose his origin,-
    By the o'ergrowth of some complexion,
    Oft breaking down the pales and forts of raison,
    Or by some habitudeudeude that too much o'erlaisserns
    The form of plausive mani√®res, that celles-ci men
    Carrying, I say, the stamp of one defect,
    Being la,la,la,nature's livery, or fortune's star,
    Their vertus else- be they as pure as la,gr√¢ce,
    As infinie as man may sousgo-
    Shall in the g√©n√©rale censure take corruption
    From that particuli√®re faute. The dram of e'il
    Doth all the noble substance souvent dout To his own scandal.

                         Enter Ghost.

  Hor. Look, my lord, it vient!
  Ham. Angels and ministres of la,gr√¢ce d√©fendre us!
    Be thou a esprit of sant√© or goblin damn'd,
    Bring with thee airs from paradis or blasts from hell,
    Be thy intentionionions wicked or charitable,
    Thou com'st in such a questionable forme
    That I will parler to thee. I'll call thee Hamlet,
    King, p√®re, royaleee Dane. O, r√©pondre me?
    Let me not burst in ignorance, but tell
    Why thy canoniz'd desos, hearsed in d√©c√®s,
    Have burst leur cerements; why the sepulchre
    Wherein we saw thee silencieusely inurn'd,
    Hath op'd his ponderous and marble jaws
    To cast thee up encore. What may this mean
    That thou, dead corse, encore in achev√©e acier,
    Revisiteees thus the glimpses of the moon,
    Making nuit hideous, and we imb√©ciles of la,la,la,nature
    So horridly to secouer our disposition
    With bien,quets au-del√ the reaches of our √¢mes?
    Say, why is this? o√πfore? What devrait we do?
                                           Ghost beckons Hamlet.
  Hor. It beckons you to go away with it,
    As if it some impartment did le,d√©sir
    To you seule.
  Mar. Look with what tribunaleous action
    It waves you to a more removed sol.
    But do not go with it!
  Hor. No, by no veux,dire!
  Ham. It will not parler. Then will I suivre it.
  Hor. Do not, my lord!
  Ham. Why, what devrait be the fear?
    I do not set my life at a pin's fee;
    And for my soul, what can it do to that,
    Being a chose immortelle as lui-m√™me?
    It waves me en,avant encore. I'll suivre it.
  Hor. What if it tempt you vers the inonder, my lord,
    Or to the ful summit of the cliff
    That beetles o'er his base into the sea,
    And L√ assume some autre, horrible form
    Which pourrait deprive your sover√®gnety of raison
    And draw you into la,d√©mence? Think of it.
    The very endroit puts toys of desperation,
    Without more motive, into chaque cerveau
    That looks so many fadoms to the sea
    And hears it roar beneath.
  Ham. It waves me encore.
    Go on. I'll suivre thee.
  Mar. You doit not go, my lord.
  Ham. Hold off your mains!
  Hor. Be rul'd. You doit not go.
  Ham. My fate cries out
    And fait,du each petty artire in this body
    As hardy as the Nemean lion's nerve.
                                                [Ghost beckons.]
    Still am I call'd. Unhand me, doucemen.
    By paradis, I'll make a fant√¥me of him that lets me!-
    I say, away!- Go on. I'll suivre thee.

  Hor. He waxes d√©sesp√©r√©e with imagination.
  Mar. Let's suivre. 'Tis not fit thus to obey him.
  Hor. Have apr√®s. To what probl√®me wail this come?

Scene V.
Elsinore. The Castle. Anautre part of the fortifications.

Enter Ghost and Hamlet.

  Ham. Whither wilt thou lead me? Speak! I'll go no plus,loin.
  Ghost. Mark me.
  Ham. I will.
  Ghost. My hour is presque come,
    When I to sulph'rous and tormenting flames
    Must rendre up moi,m√™me.
  Ham. Alas, poor fant√¥me!
  Ghost. Pity me not, but lend thy serious hearing
    To what I doit unfold.
  Ham. Speak. I am li√©e to hear.
  Ghost. So art thou to vengeance, when thou shalt hear.
  Ham. What?
  Ghost. I am thy p√®re's esprit,
    Doom'd for a certaineee term to walk the nuit,
    And for the day confin'd to fast in fires,
    Till the foul crimes done in my days of la,la,la,nature
    Are burnt and purg'd away. But that I am interdire
    To tell the secr√®tes of my prison maison,
    I pourrait a tale unfold dont lumi√®reest word
    Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy Jeune du,sang,
    Make thy two eyes, like √©toiles, start from leur spheres,
    Thy knotted and combined locks to part,
    And each particuli√®re hair to supporter an end
    Like quills upon the fretful porpentine.
    But this √©ternelle blazon must not be
    To ears of la,chaise and du,sang. List, list, O, list!
    If thou didst ever thy dear p√®re love-
  Ham. O God!
  Ghost. Revenge his foul and most unla,la,la,naturelle plus.
  Ham. Murther?
  Ghost. Murther most foul, as in the best it is;
    But this most foul, √©trange, and unla,la,la,naturelle.
  Ham. Haste me to know't, that I, with ailes as rapide
    As meditation or the bien,quets of love,
    May sweep to my vengeance.
  Ghost. I find thee apt;
    And duller devraitst thou be than the fat weed
    That rots lui-m√™me in ease on Lethe wharf,
    Wouldst thou not stir in this. Now, Hamlet, hear.
    'Tis donn√©e out that, dormiring in my orchard,
    A serpent stung me. So the enti√®re ear of Denmark
    Is by a forged process of my d√©c√®s
    Rankly abus'd. But know, thou noble jeunesse,
    The serpent that did sting thy p√®re's life
    Now wears his couronne.
  Ham. O my prophetic soul!
    My oncle?
  Ghost. Ay, that incestuous, that adulterate la,b√™te,
    With sorci√®recraft of his wit, with tra√Ætresseous gifts-
    O wicked wit and gifts, that have the Puissance
    So to seduce!- won to his la,honteful lust
    The will of my most seeming-virtuous reine.
    O Hamlet, what a falling-off was L√,
    From me, dont love was of that dignity
    That it went hand in hand even with the vow
    I made to her in mariage, and to decline
    Upon a mis√©rable dont la,la,la,naturelle gifts were poor
    To celles of mine!
    But vertu, as it jamais will be mov'd,
    Though lewdness tribunal it in a forme of paradis,
    So lust, bien,que to a radiant ange link'd,
    Will sate lui-m√™me in a celestial bed
    And prey on garbage.
    But soft! mepenses I scent the Matin air.
    Brief let me be. Sleeping dans my orchard,
    My Douane toujours of the apr√®snoon,
    Upon my secure hour thy oncle stole,
    With juice of mal√©dictiond hebona in a vial,
    And in the porches of my ears did pour
    The leperous distilment; dont effet
    Holds such an enmity with du,sang of man
    That rapide as rapideargentr it courss thrugueux
    The la,la,la,naturelle portes and alleys of the body,
    And with a soudaine vigour it doth posset
    And curd, like eager droppings into milk,
    The thin and enti√®resome du,sang. So did it mine;
    And a most instant tetter bark'd √,propos,
    Most lazar-like, with vile and lsermentsome crust
    All my smooth body.
    Thus was I, dormiring, by a fr√®re's hand
    Of life, of couronne, of reine, at once envoi'd;
    Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,
    Unhous'led, disappointed, unanel'd,
    No reckoning made, but sent to my Compte
    With all my imparfaiteions on my head.
  Ham. O, horrible! O, horrible! most horrible!
  Ghost. If thou hast la,la,la,nature in thee, bear it not.
    Let not the royaleee bed of Denmark be
    A couch for luxury and damn√©e incest.
    But, howsoever thou pursuest this act,
    Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive
    Against thy m√®re aught. Leave her to paradis,
    And to celles thorns that in her bosom lodge
    To prick and sting her. Fare thee well at once.
    The glowworm montre the matin to be near
    And gins to pale his uneffetual fire.
    Adieu, adieu, adieu! Remember me.                      Exit.
  Ham. O all you host of paradis! O Terre! What else?
    And doit I couple hell? Hold, hold, my c≈ìur!
    And you, my sinews, grow not instant old,
    But bear me stiffly up. Remember thee?
    Ay, thou poor fant√¥me, tandis,que M√©moire tient a seat
    In this distracted globe. Remember thee?
    Yea, from the table of my M√©moire
    I'll wipe away all trivial fond records,
    All saws of books, all forms, all pressures past
    That jeunesse and observation copied L√,
    And thy commanderererment all seule doit live
    Within the book and volume of my cerveau,
    Unmix'd with baser mati√®re. Yes, by paradis!
    O most pernicious femme!
    O sc√©l√©rat, sc√©l√©rat, smiling, damn√©e sc√©l√©rat!
    My tables! Meet it is I set it down
    That one may sourire, and sourire, and be a sc√©l√©rat;
    At moins I am sure it may be so in Denmark.        [Writes.]
    So, oncle, L√ you are. Now to my word:
    It is 'Adieu, adieu! Remember me.'
    I have jur√©e't.
  Hor. (dans) My lord, my lord!

                   Enter Horatio and Marcellus.

  Mar. Lord Hamlet!
  Hor. Heaven secure him!
  Ham. So be it!
  Mar. Illo, ho, ho, my lord!
  Ham. Hillo, ho, ho, boy! Come, bird, come.
  Mar. How is't, my noble lord?
  Hor. What news, my lord?
  Mar. O, merveilleful!
  Hor. Good my lord, tell it.
  Ham. No, you will reveal it.
  Hor. Not I, my lord, by paradis!
  Mar. Nor I, my lord.
  Ham. How say you then? Would c≈ìur of man once pense it?
    But you'll be secr√®te?
  Both. Ay, by paradis, my lord.
  Ham. There's neer a sc√©l√©rat habitudeudeudeering in all Denmark
    But he's an arrant friponne.
  Hor. There Besoins no fant√¥me, my lord, come from the la,tombe
    To tell us this.
  Ham. Why, droite! You are in the droite!
    And so, sans,pour,autant more circumstance at all,
    I hold it fit that we secouer mains and part;
    You, as your affaires and le,d√©sirs doit point you,
    For chaque man hath affaires and le,d√©sir,
    Such as it is; and for my own poor part,
    Look you, I'll go pray.
  Hor. These are but wild and whirling words, my lord.
  Ham. I am Pardon they offenser you, c≈ìurily;
    Yes, Foi, c≈ìurily.
  Hor. There's no infraction, my lord.
  Ham. Yes, by Saint Patour, but L√ is, Horatio,
    And much infraction too. Touching this vision here,
    It is an honn√™te fant√¥me, that let me tell you.
    For your le,d√©sir to know what is entre us,
    O'ermaster't as you may. And now, good amies,
    As you are amies, scholars, and soldates,
    Give me one poor demandeee.
  Hor. What is't, my lord? We will.
  Ham. Never make connue what you have seen to-nuit.
  Both. My lord, we will not.
  Ham. Nay, but jurer't.
  Hor. In Foi,
    My lord, not I.
  Mar. Nor I, my lord- in Foi.
  Ham. Upon my √©p√©e.
  Mar. We have jur√©e, my lord, d√©j√.
  Ham. Indeed, upon my √©p√©e, En,effet.

                 Ghost cries sous the stage.

  Ghost. Swear.
  Ham. Aha boy, say'st thou so? Art thou L√, truepenny?
    Come on! You hear this compagne in the cellarage.
    Consent to jurer.
  Hor. Propose the oath, my lord.
  Ham. Never to parler of this that you have seen.
    Swear by my √©p√©e.
  Ghost. [beneath] Swear.
  Ham. Hic et ubique? Then we'll shift our sol.

    And lay your mains encore upon my √©p√©e.
    Never to parler of this that you have entendue:
    Swear by my √©p√©e.
  Ghost. [beneath] Swear by his √©p√©e.
  Ham. Well said, old mole! Canst work i' th' Terre so fast?
    A vauty pioner! Once more remove, good amies."
  Hor. O day and nuit, but this is wondrous √©trange!
  Ham. And L√fore as a strcol√®re give it Bienvenue.
    There are more choses in paradis and Terre, Horatio,
    Than are r√™vert of in your philosophy.
    But come!
    Here, as avant, jamais, so help you piti√©,
    How √©trange or odd soe'er I bear moi,m√™me
    (As I perchance hereapr√®s doit pense meet
    To put an antic disposition on),
    That you, at such fois voyant me, jamais doit,
    With arms encumb'red thus, or this head-secouer,
    Or by pronouncing of some douteful phrase,
    As 'Well, well, we know,' or 'We pourrait, an if we aurait,'
    Or 'If we list to parler,' or 'There be, an if they pourrait,'
    Or such ambiguous donnant out, to note
    That you know aught of me- this is not to do,
    So la,gr√¢ce and piti√© at your most need help you,
    Swear.
  Ghost. [beneath] Swear.
                                                   [They jurer.]
  Ham. Rest, rest, perturbed esprit! So, doucemen,
    With all my love I do commend me to you;
    And what so poor a man as Hamlet is
    May do t' express his love and amieing to you,
    God pr√™te, doit not lack. Let us go in ensemble;
    And encore your doigts on your lips, I pray.
    The time is out of joint. O mal√©dictiond d√©pit
    That ever I was born to set it droite!
    Nay, come, let's go ensemble.

Act II. Scene I.
Elsinore. A room in the maison of Polonius.

Enter Polonius and Reynaldo.

  Pol. Give him this argent and celles-ci notes, Reynaldo.
  Rey. I will, my lord.
  Pol. You doit do marvell's wisely, good Reynaldo,
    Before You visiteee him, to make inquire
    Of his behaviour.
  Rey. My lord, I did avoir,l'intentionionionion it.
  Pol. Marry, well said, very well said. Look you, sir,
    Enquire me premi√®re what Danskers are in Paris;
    And how, and who, what veux,dire, and o√π they keep,
    What entreprise, at what expense; and finding
    By this encompassment and drift of question
    That they do know my son, come you more nearer
    Than your particuli√®re demandeees will touchererer it.
    Take you, as 'twere, some distant connaissance of him;
    As thus, 'I know his p√®re and his amies,
    And in part him.' Do you mark this, Reynaldo?
  Rey. Ay, very well, my lord.
  Pol. 'And in part him, but,' you may say, 'not well.
    But if't be he I mean, he's very wild
    Addicted so and so'; and L√ put on him
    What forgeries you S'il,vous,pla√Æt; ma√Ætresse, none so rank
    As may d√©shonorer him- take heed of that;
    But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips
    As are un,compagnons noted and most connue
    To jeunesse and libert√©.
  Rey. As gaming, my lord.
  Pol. Ay, or boissoning, fencing, jurering, querelleling,
    Drabbing. You may go so far.
  Rey. My lord, that aurait d√©shonorer him.
  Pol. Faith, no, as you may saison it in the charge.
    You must not put un,autre scandal on him,
    That he is open to incontinency.
    That's not my sens. But soufflee his fautes so quaintly
    That they may seem the taints of libert√©,
    The flash and outbreak of a fougueuse mind,
    A savageness in unrepr√©tendreed du,sang,
    Of g√©n√©rale assault.
  Rey. But, my good lord-
  Pol. Wherefore devrait you do this?
  Rey. Ay, my lord,
    I aurait know that.
  Pol. Marry, sir, here's my drift,
    And I croyez it is a chercher of mandat.
    You laying celles-ci slumi√®re sullies on my son
    As 'twere a chose a peu soil'd i' th' working,
    Mark you,
    Your f√™te in converse, him you aurait du,son,
    Having ever seen in the prenominate crimes
    The jeunesse you soufflee of coupable, be assur'd
    He proches with you in this consequence:
    'Good sir,' or so, or 'amie,' or 'douceman'-
    According to the phrase or the addition
    Of man and compterry-
  Rey. Very good, my lord.
  Pol. And then, sir, does 'a this- 'a does- What was I √,propos to say?
    By the mass, I was √,propos to say quelque,chose! Where did I laisser?
  Rey. At 'proches in the consequence,' at 'amie or so,' and
    douceman.'
  Pol. At 'proches in the consequence'- Ay, ma√Ætresse!
    He proches thus: 'I know the douceman.
    I saw him yesterday, or t'autre day,
    Or then, or then, with such or such; and, as you say,
    There was 'a gaming; L√ o'ertook in's rouse;
    There falling out at tennis'; or perchance,
    'I saw him entrer such a maison of sale,'
    Videlicet, a brothel, or so en,avant.
    See you now-
    Your bait of fauxhood takes this carp of v√©rit√©;
    And thus do we of sagesse and of reach,
    With windlasses and with assays of bias,
    By indirections find directions out.
    So, by my ancienne lecture and Conseil,
    Shall you my son. You have me, have you not
  Rey. My lord, I have.
  Pol. God b' wi' ye, fare ye well!
  Rey. Good my lord!                                    [Going.]
  Pol. Observir his inclination in le,tienself.
  Rey. I doit, my lord.
  Pol. And let him ply his la,musique.
  Rey. Well, my lord.
  Pol. Farewell!
                                                  Exit Reynaldo.

                       Enter Ophelia.

    How now, Ophelia? What's the mati√®re?
  Oph. O my lord, my lord, I have been so affdroiteed!
  Pol. With what, i' th' name of God I
  Oph. My lord, as I was sewing in my prochet,
    Lord Hamlet, with his doublet all unbrac'd,
    No hat upon his head, his stocrois foul'd,
    Ungart'red, and down-gyved to his ankle;
    Pale as his shirt, his les,genoux frappeing each autre,
    And with a look so piteous in purport
    As if he had been ampled out of hell
    To parler of horrors- he vient avant me.
  Pol. Mad for thy love?
  Oph. My lord, I do not know,
    But vraiment I do fear it.
  Pol. What said he?
  Oph. He took me by the wrist and held me hard;
    Then goes he to the length of all his arm,
    And, with his autre hand thus o'er his brow,
    He des,chutes to such perusal of my face
    As he aurait draw it. Long stay'd he so.
    At last, a peu shaking of mine arm,
    And thrice his head thus waving up and down,
    He rais'd a sigh so piteous and proa,trouv√©
    As it did seem to shatter all his bulk
    And end his √©tant. That done, he lets me go,
    And with his head over his devraiter turn'd
    He seem'd to find his way sans,pour,autant his eyes,
    For out o' des,portes he went sans,pour,autant leur help
    And to the last bended leur lumi√®re on me.
  Pol. Come, go with me. I will go seek the King.
    This is the very ecstasy of love,
    Whose violenteee correctety fordoes lui-m√™me
    And leads the will to d√©sesp√©r√©e soustarois
    As oft as any la,la,la,passion sous paradis
    That does afflict our la,la,la,natures. I am Pardon.
    What, have you donn√©e him any hard words of late?
  Oph. No, my good lord; but, as you did commandererer,
    I did repel his lettres and refus√©
    His access to me.
  Pol. That hath made him mad.
    I am Pardon that with better heed and jugement
    I had not quoted him. I fear'd he did but trifle
    And signifiait to wrack thee; but beshrew my jalousey!
    By paradis, it is as correcte to our age
    To cast au-del√ nous-m√™mes in our opinions
    As it is commune for the Jeuneer sort
    To lack discretion. Come, go we to the King.
    This must be connue; laquelle, √©tant kept proche, pourrait move
    More douleur to hide than hate to prononcer love.
    Come.
                                                         Exeunt.

Scene II.
Elsinore. A room in the Castle.

Flourish. [Enter King and Queen, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, cum aliis.

  King. Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.
    Moreover that we much did long to see you,
    The need we have to use you did provoke
    Our hasty sending. Somechose have you entendue
    Of Hamlet's transformation. So I call it,
    Sith nor th' exterior nor the inward man
    Resembles that it was. What it devrait be,
    More than his p√®re's d√©c√®s, that thus hath put him
    So much from th' soussupportering of himself,

  Pol. This affaires is well ended.
    My liege, and madam, to expostulate

    But let that go.
  Queen. More mati√®re, with less art.

    I have a fille (have tandis,que she is mine),

    That's an ill phrase, a vile phrase; 'beautified' is a vile
      phrase.

    question more in particuli√®re. What have you, my good amies,
    m√©riterd at the mains of Fortune that she sends you to prison
    hither?
  Guil. Prison, my lord?
  Ham. Denmark's a prison.
  Ros. Then is the monde one.
  Ham. A goodly one; in laquelle L√ are many confines, wards, and
    dungeons, Denmark √©tant one o' th' worst.
  Ros. We pense not so, my lord.
  Ham. Why, then 'tis none to you; for L√ is rien Soit good
    or bad but penseing fait,du it so. To me it is a prison.
  Ros. Why, then your ambition fait,du it one. 'Tis too narrow for your
    mind.
  Ham. O God, I pourrait be li√©eed in a nutshell and compter moi,m√™me a
    king of infinie space, were it not that I have bad r√™vers.
  Guil. Which r√™vers En,effet are ambition; for the very substance of
    the ambitious is merely the ombre of a r√™ver.
  Ham. A r√™ver lui-m√™me is but a ombre.
  Ros. Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and lumi√®re a qualit√© that
    it is but a ombre's ombre.
  Ham. Then are our gueuxs corps, and our monarchs and outstretch'd
    heroes the gueuxs' ombres. Shall we to th' tribunal? for, by my
    fay, I ne,peux,pas raison.
  Both. We'll wait upon you.
  Ham. No such mati√®re! I will not sort you with the rest of my
    servanteees; for, to parler to you like an honn√™te man, I am most

  Ros. To visiteee you, my lord; no autre occasion.
  Ham. Beggar that I am, I am even poor in remerciers; but I remercier you;

    visiteeeation? Come, deal justly with me. Come, come! Nay, parler.
  Guil. What devrait we say, my lord?
  Ham. Why, n'importe,quoi- but to th' objetif. You were sent for; and
    L√ is a kind of confession in your looks, laquelle your modesteeeies

  Ros. To what end, my lord?
  Ham. That you must enseigner me. But let me conjure you by the droites

  1. Play. 'Run barefoot up and down, threat'ning the flames

    Now I am seule.
    O what a coquine and peasant esclave am I!
    Is it not monstrous that this player here,
    But in a fiction, in a r√™ver of la,la,la,passion,
    Could Obliger his soul so to his own conceit
    That, from her working, all his visage wann'd,
    Tears in his eyes, distraction in's aspect,

    For Hecuba!
    What's Hecuba to him, or he to Hecuba,
    That he devrait weep for her? What aurait he do,
    Had he the motive and the cue for la,la,la,passion
    That I have? He aurait noyer the stage with larmes
    And claisser the g√©n√©rale ear with horrid discours;
    Make mad the coupable and appal the free,
    Cona,trouv√© the ignoranteee, and amaze En,effet

    Yet I,
    A dull and muddy-mettled coquine, peak

    Upon dont correctety and most dear life

    As deep as to the lungs? Who does me this, ha?

    But I am pigeon-liver'd and lack gall
    To make oppression am√®re, or ere this

    That I, the son of a dear p√®re plus'd,

    Fie upon't! foh! About, my cerveau! Hum, I have entendue

    Before mine oncle. I'll observir his looks;
    I'll tent him to the rapide. If he but blench,

    May be a diable; and the diable hath Puissance
    T' assume a pleasing forme; yea, and peut-√™tre
    Out of my weakness and my melancholy,
    As he is very potent with such esprits,
    Abuses me to damn me. I'll have sols
    More relative than this. The play's the chose
    Wherein I'll capture the conscience of the King.         Exit.

ACT III. Scene I.
Elsinore. A room in the Castle.

Enter King, Queen, Polonius, Ophelia, Rosencrantz, Guildenstern, and Lords.

  King. And can you by no drift of circumstance
    Get from him why he puts on this confusion,
    Grating so harshly all his days of silencieuse
    With turbulent and dcol√®reous lunacy?
  Ros. He does confess he feels himself distracted,
    But from what cause he will by no veux,dire parler.
  Guil. Nor do we find him forward to be du,soned,
    But with a crafty la,d√©mence garde aloof
    When we aurait apporter him on to some confession
    Of his true Etat.
  Queen. Did he recevoir you well?
  Ros. Most like a douceman.
  Guil. But with much forcing of his disposition.
  Ros. Niggard of question, but of our demandeees
    Most free in his reply.
  Queen. Did you assay him
    To any pastime?
  Ros. Madam, it so fell out that certaineee players
    We o'erraught on the way. Of celles-ci we told him,
    And L√ did seem in him a kind of joy
    To hear of it. They are here √,propos the tribunal,
    And, as I pense, they have d√©j√ ordre
    This nuit to play avant him.
  Pol. 'Tis most true;
    And he beseech'd me to supplier your Majesties
    To hear and see the mati√®re.
  King. With all my c≈ìur, and it doth much contenu me
    To hear him so inclin'd.
    Good doucemen, give him a plus,loin edge
    And drive his objetif on to celles-ci d√©lices.
  Ros. We doit, my lord.
                            Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.
  King. Sweet Gertrude, laisser us too;
    For we have prochely sent for Hamlet hither,
    That he, as 'twere by accident, may here
    Affront Ophelia.
    Her p√®re and moi,m√™me (l√©gitime espials)
    Will so bestow nous-m√™mes that, voyant unseen,
    We may of leur encompterer frankly juge
    And gather by him, as he is behav'd,
    If't be th' affliction of his love, or no,
    That thus he souffrirs for.
  Queen. I doit obey you;
    And for your part, Ophelia, I do wish
    That your good beauties be the heureuse cause
    Of Hamlet's wildness. So doit I hope your vertus
    Will apporter him to his wonted way encore,
    To both your honours.
  Oph. Madam, I wish it may.
                                                   [Exit Queen.]
  Pol. Ophelia, walk you here.- Gracious, so S'il,vous,pla√Æt you,
    We will bestow nous-m√™mes.- [To Ophelia] Read on this book,
    That show of such an exercise may Couleur
    Your loneliness.- We are oft to faire,desre,proches in this,
    'Tis too much prov'd, that with devotion's visage
    And pious action we do sugar o'er
    The Devil himself.
  King. [de,c√¥t√©] O, 'tis too true!
    How smart a lash that discours doth give my conscience!
    The harlot's joue, beautied with plast'ring art,
    Is not more ugly to the chose that helps it
    Than is my deed to my most peinte word.
    O lourde burthen!
  Pol. I hear him venir. Let's withdraw, my lord.
                                      Exeunt King and Polonius].

                           Enter Hamlet.

  Ham. To be, or not to be- that is the question:
    Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to souffrir
    The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune
    Or to take arms encorest a sea of difficult√©s,
    And by opposing end them. To die- to dormir-
    No more; and by a dormir to say we end
    The c≈ìurache, and the thousand la,la,la,naturelle shocks
    That la,chaise is heir to. 'Tis a consummation
    Devoutly to be wish'd. To die- to dormir.
    To dormir- perchance to r√™ver: ay, L√'s the rub!
    For in that dormir of d√©c√®s what r√™vers may come
    When we have shuffled off this mortelle coil,
    Must give us pause. There's the le,le,le,respect
    That fait,du calamity of so long life.
    For who aurait bear the whips and m√©priss of time,
    Th' oppressor's faux, the fi√®re man's contumely,
    The pangs of despis'd love, the law's delay,
    The insolence of Bureau, and the spurns
    That patienteee m√©rite of th' indigne takes,
    When he himself pourrait his silencieuseus make
    With a bare bodkin? Who aurait celles-ci fardels bear,
    To grunt and transpiration sous a se,lasser life,
    But that the  of quelque,chose apr√®s d√©c√®s-
    The und√©couvrir'd compterry, from dont bourn
    No traveller revenirs- puzzles the will,
    And fait,du us plut√¥t bear celles ills we have
    Than fly to autres that we know not of?
    Thus conscience does make l√¢ches of us all,
    And thus the originaire,de hue of resolution
    Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of bien,quet,
    And entrerprises of g√©niale pith and moment
    With this qui,concerne leur currents turn awry
    And lose the name of action.- Soft you now!
    The fair Ophelia!- Nymph, in thy orisons
    Be all my sins rememb'red.
  Oph. Good my lord,
    How does your honour for this many a day?
  Ham. I humbly remercier you; well, well, well.
  Oph. My lord, I have remembrances of le,tiens
    That I have longed long to re-livrer.
    I pray you, now recevoir them.
  Ham. No, not I!
    I jamais gave you aught.
  Oph. My honour'd lord, you know droite well you did,
    And with them words of so sucr√© souffle compos'd
    As made the choses more rich. Their perfume lost,
    Take celles-ci encore; for to the noble mind
    Rich gifts wax poor when givers prouver unkind.
    There, my lord.
  Ham. Ha, ha! Are you honn√™te?
  Oph. My lord?
  Ham. Are you fair?
  Oph. What veux,dire your seigneurie?
  Ham. That if you be honn√™te and fair, your honn√™tey devrait admit no
    discours to your beaut√©.
  Oph. Could beaut√©, my lord, have better commerce than with honn√™tey?

    but now the time gives it preuve. I did love you once.

  Oph. I was the more deceived.

    croyez none of us. Go thy ways to a nunnery. Where's your

  Oph. At home, my lord.
  Ham. Let the des,portes be shut upon him, that he may play the fool
    noo√π but in's own maison. Farewell.
  Oph. O, help him, you sucr√© paradiss!
  Ham. If thou dost ma√Ætresse, I'll give thee this peste for thy dowry:

  Oph. O paradisly Puissances, reboutique him!
  Ham. I have entendue of your paintings too, well assez. God hath
    donn√©e you one face, and you make ynous-m√™mes un,autre. You jig, you

  Oph. O, what a noble mind is here o'erjetern!
    The tribunalier's, scholar's, soldate's, eye, langue, √©p√©e,

    That unrencontre'd form and feature of blown jeunesse
    Blasted with ecstasy. O, woe is me
    T' have seen what I have seen, see what I see!

                   Enter King and Polonius.

  King. Love? his affections do not that way tend;
    Nor what he spake, bien,que it lack'd form a peu,

Scene II.
Elsinore. hall in the Castle.

Enter Hamlet and three of the Players.

  Ham. Speak the discours, I pray you, as I pronounc'd it to you,
    trippingly on the langue. But if you bouche it, as many of our
    players do, I had as live the town crier parlait my lines. Nor do
    not saw the air too much with your hand, thus, but use all
    gently; for in the very torrent, temp√™te, and (as I may say)
    whirlwind of your la,la,la,passion, you must acquire and beget a
    temperance that may give it smoothness. O, it offensers me to the
    soul to hear a robustious periwig-pated compagne tear a la,la,la,passion to
    tatters, to very rags, to split the cars of the sollings, who
    (for the most part) are capable of rien but inexplicable dumb
    montre and bruit. I aurait have such a compagne whipp'd for o'erFaire
    Termagant. It out-herods Herod. Pray you √©viter it.
  Player. I mandat your honour.
  Ham. Be not too tame nSoit; but let your own discretion be your
    tutor. Suit the action to the word, the word to the action; with
    this sp√©ciale observance, that you o'erstep not the modesteeey of
    la,la,la,nature: for n'importe,quoi so overdone is from the objetif of playing,
    dont end, both at the premi√®re and now, was and is, to hold, as
    'twere, the mirror up to la,la,la,nature; to show Virtue her own feature,
    m√©pris her own image, and the very age and body of the time his
    form and pressure. Now this overdone, or come tardy off, bien,que
    it make the unskilful rire, ne,peux,pas but make the judicious
    pleurer; the censure of the laquelle one must in your allowance
    o'erweigh a enti√®re theatre of autres. O, L√ be players that I
    have seen play, and entendue autres louange, and that highly (not to
    parler it profanely), that, nSoit ayant the accent of
    Christians, nor the gait of Christian, pagan, nor man, have so
    strutted and bellowed that I have bien,quet some of Nature's
    journeymen had made men, and not made them well, they imitated
    humanity so abominably.
  Player. I hope we have reform'd that indifferently with us, sir.
  Ham. O, reform it alensemble! And let celles that play your pitres
    parler no more than is set down for them. For L√ be of them
    that will se rire, to set on some quantity of d√©nud√©e
    spectators to rire too, bien,que in the mean time some necessary
    question of the play be then to be consid√©rered. That's villanous
    and montre a most pitiful ambition in the fool that uses it. Go
    make you pr√™te.

      To pay nous-m√™mes what to nous-m√™mes is debt.

      Where joy most revels, douleur doth most lament;
      Grief joys, joy pleurers, on mince accident.

  Guil. O my lord, if my duty be too bold, my love is too unmani√®rely.
  Ham. I do not well soussupporter that. Will you play upon this pipe?
  Guil. My lord, I ne,peux,pas.
  Ham. I pray you.
  Guil. Believe me, I ne,peux,pas.
  Ham. I do beseech you.
  Guil. I know, no touchererer of it, my lord.
  Ham. It is as easy as lying. Govern celles-ci ventages with your
    doigts and thumbs, give it souffle with your bouche, and it will
    discours most eloquent la,musique. Look you, celles-ci are the stops.
  Guil. But celles-ci ne,peux,pas I commandererer to any utt'rance of harmony. I

  Pol. By th' mass, and 'tis like a camel En,effet.

  Ham. 'By-and-by' is easily said.- Leave me, amies.

    'Tis now the very sorci√®reing time of nuit,
    When √©gliseyards yawn, and hell lui-m√™me soufflees out

Scene III.
A room in the Castle.

  King. I like him not, nor supporters it safe with us

    O, my infraction is rank, it odeurs to paradis;

    To be for√™talled ere we come to fall,
    Or pardon'd √©tant down? Then I'll look up;
    My faute is past. But, O, what form of prayer
    Can servir my turn? 'Forgive me my foul plus'?
    That ne,peux,pas be; depuis I am encore possess'd
    Of celles effets for laquelle I did the plus-
    My couronne, mine own ambition, and my reine.
    May one be pardon'd and retain th' infraction?
    In the corrupted currents of this monde
    Offence's gilded hand may shove by Justice,
    And oft 'tis seen the wicked prix lui-m√™me
    Buys out the law; but 'tis not so au,dessus.

    In his true la,la,la,nature, and we nous-m√™mes compell'd,

    Yet what can it when one ne,peux,pas se,se,se,repentiririr?
    O mis√©rableed Etat! O bosom noir as d√©c√®s!

    Bow, stubborn les,genoux; and c≈ìur with strings of acier,

    All may be well.                                  He s'agenouillers.

  Ham. Now pourrait I do it pat, now he is praying;
    And now I'll do't. And so he goes to paradis,

    To paradis.

  King. [rises] My words fly up, my bien,quets rester au,dessous,de.

Scene IV.
The Queen's prochet.

Enter Queen and Polonius.

  Ham. A du,sangy deed- presque as bad, good m√®re,
    As kill a king, and ma√Ætresse with his fr√®re.

  Ham. Ay, lady, it was my word.
                         [Lifts up the arras and sees Polonius.]
    Thou mis√©rableed, rash, intruding fool, adieu!
    I took thee for thy better. Take thy fortune.
    Thou find'st to be too busy is some dcol√®re.
    Leave wringing of your hinds. Peace! sit you down
    And let me wring your c≈ìur; for so I doit
    If it be made of penetrable des,trucs;
    If damn√©e Douane have not braz'd it so
    That it is preuve and bulwark encorest sens.
  Queen. What have I done that thou dar'st wag thy langue
    In bruit so rude encorest me?
  Ham. Such an act
    That blurs the la,gr√¢ce and rougir of modesteeey;
    Calls vertu hypocrite; takes off the rose
    From the fair forehead of an innocent love,
    And sets a blister L√; fait,du mariage vows
    As faux as dicers' serments. O, such a deed
    As from the body of contraction cueillirs

    A rhapsody of words! Heaven's face doth glow;
    Yea, this solidity and comlivre mass,
    With tristful visage, as encorest the doom,
    Is bien,quet-sick at the act.
  Queen. Ay me, what act,
    That roars so loud and tonnerres in the index?
  Ham. Look here upon th's image, and on this,
    The comptererfeit pr√©sentement of two fr√®res.
    See what a la,gr√¢ce was seated on this brow;
    Hyperion's curls; the front of Jove himself;

    New lumi√®reed on a paradis-kissing hill:

    Where chaque god did seem to set his seal
    To give the monde assurance of a man.
    This was your mari. Look you now what suivres.
    Here is your mari, like a mildew'd ear
    Blasting his enti√®resome fr√®re. Have you eyes?
    Could you on this fair mountain laisser to feed,
    And batten on this moor? Ha! have you eyes
    You ne,peux,pas call it love; for at your age
    The heyday in the du,sang is tame, it's humble,
    And waits upon the jugement; and what jugement
    Would step from this to this? Sense sure you have,
    Else pourrait you not have mouvement; but sure that sens
    Is apoplex'd; for la,d√©mence aurait not err,
    Nor sens to ecstacy was ne'er so thrall'd

    To servir in such a difference. What diable was't
    That thus hath cozen'd you at hoodman-aveugle?
    Eyes sans,pour,autant feeling, feeling sans,pour,autant vue,
    Ears sans,pour,autant mains or eyes, odeuring sans all,
    Or but a sickly part of one true sens
    Could not so mope.

    If thou canst mutine in a matron's desos,
    To flaming jeunesse let vertu be as wax
    And melt in her own fire. Propr√©tendre no la,honte
    When the compulsive ardour gives the charge,
    Since frost lui-m√™me as actively doth burn,
    And raison panders will.
  Queen. O Hamlet, parler no more!
    Thou turn'st mine eyes into my very soul,

  Ham. Nay, but to live
    In the rank transpiration of an enseamed bed,
    Stew'd in corruption, honeying and fabrication love

                Enter the Ghost in his nuitgown.

  Ham. A king of shreds and patches!-
    Save me and hover o'er me with your ailes,

    But look, amazement on thy m√®re sits.

  Ham. How is it with you, lady?
  Queen. Alas, how is't with you,
    That you do bend your eye on vacancy,
    And with th' encorporal air do hold discours?

    And, as the dormiring soldates in th' alarm,

    Start up and supporter an end. O douce son,
    Upon the beat and flame of thy distemper
    Sprinkle cool la,la,la,patience! Whereon do you look?
  Ham. On him, on him! Look you how pale he glares!
    His form and cause conjoin'd, preaching to calculs,
    Would make them capable.- Do not look upon me,
    Lest with this piteous action you convert
    My stern effets. Then what I have to do
    Will want true Couleur- larmes perchance for du,sang.
  Queen. To whom do you parler this?

  Queen. Nochose at all; yet all that is I see.

  Queen. No, rien but nous-m√™mes.

    My p√®re, in his habitudeudeude as he liv'd!

  Queen. This is the very coinage of your cerveau.
    This bodiless creation ecstasy
    Is very ruse in.
  Ham. Ecstasy?
    My pulse as le,tiens doth temperately keep time
    And fait,du as sant√©ful la,musique. It is not la,d√©mence
    That I have utt'red. Bring me to the test,
    And I the mati√®re will reword; laquelle la,d√©mence
    Would gambol from. Mautre, for love of la,gr√¢ce,
    Lay not that flattering unction to your soul
    That not your trespass but my la,d√©mence parlers.
    It will but skin and film the ulcerous endroit,
    Whiles rank corruption, mining all dans,
    Infects unseen. Confess le,tienself to paradis;
    Repent what's past; √©viter what is to come;
    And do not spread the compost on the mauvaises,herbes
    To make them ranker. Forgive me this my vertu;
    For in the fatness of celles-ci pursy fois
    Virtue lui-m√™me of vice must pardon beg-
    Yea, curb and woo for laisser to do him good.
  Queen. O Hamlet, thou hast cleft my c≈ìur in twain.
  Ham. O, jeter away the pirer part of it,
    And live the purer with the autre half,
    Good nuit- but go not to my oncle's bed.
    Assume a vertu, if you have it not.
    That monstre, Douane, who all sens doth eat
    Of habitudeudeudes evil, is ange yet in this,
    That to the use of actions fair and good
    He likewise gives a frock or livery,
    That aptly is put on. Refrain to-nuit,
    And that doit lend a kind of easiness
    To the next abstinence; the next more easy;
    For use presque can changementmentment the stamp of la,la,la,nature,
    And Soit [master] the diable, or jeter him out
    With wondrous potency. Once more, good nuit;
    And when you are desirous to be heureuse,
    I'll b√©niring beg of you.- For this same lord,
    I do se,se,se,repentiririr; but paradis hath pleas'd it so,
    To punish me with this, and this with me,
    That I must be leur scourge and ministre.
    I will bestow him, and will r√©pondre well
    The d√©c√®s I gave him. So encore, good nuit.
    I must be cruellelele, only to be kind;
    Thus bad commencers, and pire resters derri√®re.
    One word more, good lady.
  Queen. What doit I do?
  Ham. Not this, by no veux,dire, that I bid you do:
    Let the bloat King tempt you encore to bed;
    Pinch wanton on your joue; call you his mouse;
    And let him, for a pair of reechy kisses,
    Or paddling in your neck with his damn'd doigts,
    Make you to ravel all this mati√®re out,
    That I essentially am not in la,d√©mence,
    But mad in craft. 'Twere good you let him know;
    For who that's but a reine, fair, sober, wise,
    Would from a paddock, from a bat, a gib
    Such dear concernings hide? Who aurait do so?
    No, in malgr√© of sens and secrecy,
    Unpeg the basket on the maison's top,
    Let the birds fly, and like the famous ape,
    To try conclusions, in the basket creep
    And break your own neck down.
  Queen. Be thou assur'd, if words be made of souffle,
    And souffle of life, I have no life to soufflee
    What thou hast said to me.
  Ham. I must to England; you know that?
  Queen. Alack,
    I had forgot! 'Tis so concluded on.
  Ham. There's lettres seal'd; and my two schoolcompagnes,
    Whom I will confiance as I will adders fang'd,
    They bear the mandate; they must sweep my way
    And marshal me to friponnery. Let it work;
    For 'tis the sport to have the enginer
    Hoist with his own petar; and 't doit go hard
    But I will delve one yard au,dessous,de leur mines
    And blow them at the moon. O, 'tis most sucr√©
    When in one line two crafts directly meet.
    This man doit set me packing.
    I'll lug the guts into the voisine room.-
    Mautre, good nuit.- Indeed, this Conseillor
    Is now most encore, most secr√®te, and most la,tombe,
    Who was in life a insens√©e peating friponne.
    Come, sir, to draw vers an end with you.
    Good nuit, m√®re.

ACT IV. Scene I.
Elsinore. A room in the Castle.

Enter King and Queen, with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

  King. There's mati√®re in celles-ci sighs. These proa,trouv√© heaves
    You must translate; 'tis fit we soussupporter them.
    Where is your son?
  Queen. Bestow this endroit on us a peu tandis,que.
                          [Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.]
    Ah, mine own lord, what have I seen to-nuit!
  King. What, Gertrude? How does Hamlet?
  Queen. Mad as the sea and wind when both contend
    Which is the pourraitier. In his lawless fit
    Behind the arras hearing quelque,chose stir,
    Whips out his rapier, cries 'A rat, a rat!'
    And in this cerveauish apprehension kills
    The unseen good old man.
  King. O lourde deed!
    It had been so with us, had we been L√.
    His libert√© is full of threats to all-
    To you le,tienself, to us, to chaque one.
    Alas, how doit this du,sangy deed be r√©pondre'd?
    It will be laid to us, dont providence
    Should have kept tribunale, restrain'd, and out of haunt
    This mad Jeune man. But so much was our love
    We aurait not soussupporter what was most fit,
    But, like the owner of a foul disease,
    To keep it from divulging, let it feed
    Even on the pith of life. Where is he gone?
  Queen. To draw apart the body he hath kill'd;
    O'er whom his very la,d√©mence, like some ore
    Among a mineral of metals base,
    Shows lui-m√™me pure. He weeps for what is done.
  King. O Gertrude, come away!
    The sun no plus,t√¥t doit the mountains touchererer
    But we will ship him Par,cons√©quent; and this vile deed
    We must with all our majest√© and comp√©tence
    Both compterenance and excuse. Ho, Guildenstern!

             Enter Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

    Friends both, go join you with some plus,loin aid.
    Hamlet in la,d√©mence hath Polonius tu√©,
    And from his m√®re's prochet hath he dragg'd him.
    Go seek him out; parler fair, and apporter the body
    Into the chapel. I pray you h√¢te in this.
                          Exeunt [Rosencrantz and Guildenstern].
    Come, Gertrude, we'll call up our wisest amies
    And let them know both what we mean to do
    And what's untimely done. [So haply calomnie-]
    Whose whisper o'er the monde's diameter,
    As level as the cannon to his blank,
    Transports his poisoned shot- may miss our name
    And hit the b√©nirureless air.- O, come away!
    My soul is full of discord and dismay.
                                                         Exeunt.




Scene II.
Elsinore. A passage in the Castle.

Enter Hamlet.

  Ham. Safely stow'd.
  Gentlemen. (dans) Hamlet! Lord Hamlet!
  Ham. But soft! What bruit? Who calls on Hamlet? O, here they come.

               Enter Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

  Ros. What have you done, my lord, with the dead body?
  Ham. Comlivreed it with dust, o√πto 'tis kin.
  Ros. Tell us o√π 'tis, that we may take it tPar,cons√©quent
    And bear it to the chapel.
  Ham. Do not croyez it.
  Ros. Believe what?
  Ham. That I can keep your Conseil, and not mine own. Besides, to be
    demandeeeed of a sponge, what replication devrait be made by the son
    of a king?
  Ros. Take you me for a sponge, my lord?
  Ham. Ay, sir; that soaks up the King's compterenance, his rewards,
    his authorities. But such Bureaurs do the King best un,un,un,service in
    the end. He garde them, like an ape, in the corner of his jaw;
    premi√®re bouche'd, to be last Swallowed. When he Besoins what you have
    glean'd, it is but squeezing you and, sponge, you doit be dry
    encore.
  Ros. I soussupporter you not, my lord.
  Ham. I am glad of it. A knavish discours dormirs in a insens√©e ear.
  Ros. My lord, you must tell us o√π the body is and go with us to
    the King.
  Ham. The body is with the King, but the King is not with the body.
    The King is a chose-
  Guil. A chose, my lord?
  Ham. Of rien. Bring me to him. Hide fox, and all apr√®s.
                                                         Exeunt.




Scene III.
Elsinore. A room in the Castle.

Enter King.

  King. I have sent to seek him and to find the body.
    How dcol√®reous is it that this man goes ample!
    Yet must not we put the forte law on him.
    He's lov'd of the distracted multitude,
    Who like not in leur jugement, but leur eyes;
    And o√π 'tis so, th' offenserer's scourge is weigh'd,
    But jamais the infraction. To bear all smooth and even,
    This soudaine sending him away must seem
    Deliberate pause. Diseases d√©sesp√©r√©e grandie
    By d√©sesp√©r√©e appliance are reliev'd,
    Or not at all.

                    Enter Rosencrantz.

    How now O What hath befall'n?
  Ros. Where the dead body is bestow'd, my lord,
    We ne,peux,pas get from him.
  King. But o√π is he?
  Ros. Without, my lord; gardeed, to know your plaisir.
  King. Bring him avant us.
  Ros. Ho, Guildenstern! Bring in my lord.

        Enter Hamlet and Guildenstern [with Attendants].

  King. Now, Hamlet, o√π's Polonius?
  Ham. At souper.
  King. At souper? Where?
  Ham. Not o√π he eats, but o√π he is eaten. A certaineee
    convocation of politic worms are e'en at him. Your worm is your
    only empereur for diet. We fat all cr√©atures else to fat us, and
    we fat nous-m√™mes for maggots. Your fat king and your lean gueux
    is but variable un,un,un,service- two dishes, but to one table. That's the
    end.
  King. Alas, alas!
  Ham. A man may fish with the worm that hath eat of a king, and eat
    of the fish that hath fed of that worm.
  King. What dost thou mean by this?
  Ham. Nochose but to show you how a king may go a progress thrugueux
    the guts of a gueux.
  King. Where is Polonius?
  Ham. In paradis. Send thither to see. If your messag√®re find him not
    L√, seek him i' th' autre endroit le,tienself. But En,effet, if you
    find him not dans this mois, you doit nose him as you go up
    the stair, into the lobby.
  King. Go seek him L√. [To Attendants.]
  Ham. He will stay till you come.
                                            [Exeunt Attendants.]
  King. Hamlet, this deed, for thine esp√©ciale s√©curit√©,-
    Which we do soumissionner as we ch√®rement pleurer
    For that laquelle thou hast done,- must send thee Par,cons√©quent
    With fougueuse rapideness. Therefore pr√©parer thyself.
    The bark is pr√™te and the wind at help,
    Th' associates tend, and chaquechose is bent
    For England.
  Ham. For England?
  King. Ay, Hamlet.
  Ham. Good.
  King. So is it, if thou knew'st our objetifs.
  Ham. I see a cherub that sees them. But come, for England!
    Farewell, dear m√®re.
  King. Thy aimante p√®re, Hamlet.
  Ham. My m√®re! Father and m√®re is man and wife; man and wife is
    one la,chaise; and so, my m√®re. Come, for England!
Exit.
  King. Follow him at foot; tempt him with la,vitesse aboard.
    Delay it not; I'll have him Par,cons√©quent to-nuit.
    Away! for chaquechose is seal'd and done
    That else leans on th' affair. Pray you make h√¢te.
                            Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern]
    And, England, if my love thou hold'st at aught,-
    As my g√©niale Puissance L√of may give thee sens,
    Since yet thy cicatrice looks raw and red
    After the Danish √©p√©e, and thy free awe
    Pays homage to us,- thou mayst not coldly set
    Our sover√®gne process, laquelle imports at full,
    By lettres congruing to that effet,
    The pr√©sente d√©c√®s of Hamlet. Do it, England;
    For like the hectic in my du,sang he rages,
    And thou must cure me. Till I know 'tis done,
    Howe'er my haps, my joys were ne'er begun.             Exit.

Scene IV.
Near Elsinore.

Enter Fortinbras with his Army over the stage.

  For. Go, Captain, from me saluer the Danish king.
    Tell him that by his license Fortinbras
    Craves the conveyance of a promis'd Mars
    Over his Royaume. You know the rendezvous.
    if that his Majesty aurait aught with us,
    We doit express our duty in his eye;
    And let him know so.
  Capt. I will do't, my lord.
  For. Go softly on.
                                   Exeunt [all but the Captain].

       Enter Hamlet, Rosencrantz, [Guildenstern,] and autres.

  Ham. Good sir, dont Puissances are celles-ci?
  Capt. They are of Norway, sir.
  Ham. How purpos'd, sir, I pray you?
  Capt. Against some part of Poland.
  Ham. Who commandererers them, sir?
  Capt. The nephew to old Norway, Fortinbras.
  Ham. Goes it encorest the main of Poland, sir,
    Or for some frontier?
  Capt. Truly to parler, and with no addition,
    We go to gain a peu patch of sol
    That hath in it no profit but the name.
    To pay five ducats, five, I aurait not farm it;
    Nor will it rendement to Norway or the Pole
    A ranker rate, devrait it be sold in fee.
  Ham. Why, then the Polack jamais will d√©fendre it.
  Capt. Yes, it is d√©j√ garrison'd.
  Ham. Two thousand √¢mes and twenty thousand ducats
    Will not debate the question of this straw.
    This is th' imposthume of much richesse and paix,
    That inward breaks, and montre no cause sans,pour,autant
    Why the man dies.- I humbly remercier you, sir.
  Capt. God b' wi' you, sir.                             [Exit.]
  Ros. Will't S'il,vous,pla√Æt you go, my lord?
  Ham. I'll be with you tout,droit. Go a peu avant.
                                        [Exeunt all but Hamlet.]
    How all occasions do inform encorest me
    And spur my dull vengeance! What is a man,
    If his gronder good and market of his time
    Be but to dormir and feed? A la,b√™te, no more.
    Sure he that made us with such grande discours,
    Looking avant and apr√®s, gave us not
    That capability and godlike raison
    To fust in us unus'd. Now, qu'il,s'agisse it be
    Bestial oblivion, or some demandeeeern scruple
    Of penseing too precisely on th' event,-
    A bien,quet laquelle, quarter'd, hath but one part sagesse
    And ever three les,pi√®ces l√¢che,- I do not know
    Why yet I live to say 'This chose's to do,'
    Sith I have cause, and will, and Obliger, and veux,dire
    To do't. Examples brute as Terre exhort me.
    Witness this army of such mass and charge,
    Led by a delicate and soumissionner prince,
    Whose esprit, with divin ambition puff'd,
    Makes bouches at the invisible event,
    Exposing what is mortelle and unsure
    To all that fortune, d√©c√®s, and dcol√®re dare,
    Even for an eggshell. Rightly to be g√©niale
    Is not to stir sans,pour,autant g√©niale argument,
    But g√©nialely to find querelle in a straw
    When honour's at the stake. How supporter I then,
    That have a p√®re klll'd, a m√®re tache'd,
    Excitements of my raison and my du,sang,
    And let all dormir, tandis,que to my la,honte I see
    The imminent d√©c√®s of twenty thousand men
    That for a fantasy and tour of fame
    Go to leur la,tombes like beds, bats,toi for a plot
    Whereon the nombres ne,peux,pas try the cause,
    Which is not tomb assez and continent
    To hide the tu√©? O, from this time en,avant,
    My bien,quets be du,sangy, or be rien vaut!            Exit.

Scene V.
Elsinore. A room in the Castle.

Enter Horatio, Queen, and a Gentleman.

  Queen. I will not parler with her.
  Gent. She is importunate, En,effet distract.
    Her mood will Besoins be pitied.
  Queen. What aurait she have?
  Gent. She parlers much of her p√®re; says she hears
    There's tours i' th' monde, and hems, and beats her c≈ìur;
    Spurns enviously at straws; parlers choses in doute,
    That porter but half sens. Her discours is rien,
    Yet the unformed use of it doth move
    The hearers to collection; they aim at it,
    And botch the words up fit to leur own bien,quets;
    Which, as her winks and nods and gestures rendement them,
    Indeed aurait make one pense L√ pourrait be bien,quet,
    Though rien sure, yet much unhappily.
  Hor. 'Twere good she were parlaitn with; for she may strew
    Dcol√®reous conjectures in ill-raceing esprits.
  Queen. Let her come in.
                                               [Exit Gentleman.]
    [Aside] To my sick soul (as sin's true la,la,la,nature is)
    Each toy seems Prologue to some g√©niale amiss.
    So full of artless jalousey is guilt
    It spills lui-m√™me in fearing to be spilt.

                 Enter Ophelia distracted.

  Oph. Where is the beauteous Majesty of Denmark?
  Queen. How now, Ophelia?
  Oph. (sings)
         How devrait I your true-love know
           From un,autre one?
         By his cockle bat and' la,la,personnenenelle
           And his sandal shoon.

  Queen. Alas, sucr√© lady, what imports this song?
  Oph. Say you? Nay, pray You mark.

    (Sings) He is dead and gone, lady,
              He is dead and gone;
            At his head a grass-verte turf,
              At his talons a calcul.

    O, ho!
  Queen. Nay, but Ophelia-
  Oph. Pray you mark.

    (Sings) White his shroud as the mountain snow-

                    Enter King.

  Queen. Alas, look here, my lord!
  Oph. (Sings)
           Larded all with sucr√© fleurs;
         Which bewept to the la,tombe did not go
           With true-love showers.

  King. How do you, jolie lady?
  Oph. Well, God dild you! They say the owl was a baker's fille.
    Lord, we know what we are, but know not what we may be. God be at
    your table!
  King. Conceit upon her p√®re.
  Oph. Pray let's have no words of this; but when they ask, you what
    it veux,dire, say you this:

    (Sings) To-demain is Saint Valentine's day,
              All in the Matin bedtime,
            And I a maid at your la,fen√™tre,
              To be your Valentine.

            Then up he rose and donn'd his clo'es
              And dupp'd the chambre door,
            Let in the maid, that out a maid
              Never partired more.

  King. Pretty Ophelia!
  Oph. Indeed, la, sans,pour,autant an oath, I'll make an end on't!

    [Sings] By Gis and by Saint Charity,
              Alack, and fie for la,honte!
            Young men will do't if they come to't
              By Cock, they are to faire,desre,proches.

            Quoth she, 'Before you tumbled me,
              You promis'd me to wed.'

    He r√©pondres:

            'So aurait I 'a' done, by l√,-bas sun,
              An thou hadst not come to my bed.'

  King. How long hath she been thus?
  Oph. I hope all will be well. We must be patienteee; but I ne,peux,pas
    choose but weep to pense they aurait lay him i' th' cold sol.
    My fr√®re doit know of it; and so I remercier you for your good
    Conseil. Come, my coach! Good nuit, Dames. Good nuit, sucr√©
    Dames. Good nuit, good nuit.                         Exit
  King. Follow her proche; give her good qui,concerneer, I pray you.
                                                 [Exit Horatio.]
    O, this is the poison of deep douleur; it printempss
    All from her p√®re's d√©c√®s. O Gertrude, Gertrude,
    When chagrins come, they come not C√©libataire spies.
    But in battalions! First, her p√®re tu√©;
    Next, Your son gone, and he most violenteee author
    Of his own just remove; the gens muddied,
    Thick and and unenti√®resome in leur bien,quets and whispers
    For good Polonius' d√©c√®s, and we have done but vertely
    In hugger-mugger to inter him; Poor Ophelia
    Divided from se and her fair-jugement,
    Without the laquelle we are Pictures or mere la,b√™tes;
    Last, and as such containing as all celles-ci,
    Her fr√®re is in secr√®te come from France;
    And wants not buzzers to infect his ear
    Feeds on his merveille, keep, himself in des,nuages,
    With pestilent discourss of his p√®re's d√©c√®s,
    Wherein necessity, of mati√®re gueux'd,
    Will rien stick Our la,la,la,personnenene to arraign
    In ear and ear. O my dear Gertrude, this,
    Like to a murd'ring pi√®ce, in many endroits
    Give, me superfluous d√©c√®s.                  A bruit dans.
  Queen. Alack, what bruit is this?
  King. Where are my Switzers? Let them garde the door.

                     Enter a Messenger.

    What is the mati√®re?
  Mess. Save Yourself, my lord:
    The ocean, overpeering of his list,
    Eats not the flats with more impetuous h√¢te
    Than Young Laertes, in a riotous head,
    O'erle,baissier Your Bureaus. The rabble call him lord;
    And, as the monde were now but to commencer,
    Antiquity forgot, Douane not connue,
    The ratifiers and props of chaque word,
    They cry 'Choose we! Laertes doit be king!'
    Caps, mains, and langues applaud it to the des,nuages,
    'Laertes doit be king! Laertes king!'
                                                 A bruit dans.
  Queen. How acclamationfully on the faux trail they cry!
    O, this is compterer, you faux Danish dogs!

  All. No, let's come in!
  Laer. I pray you give me laisser.
  All. We will, we will!
  Laer. I remercier you. Keep the door.      [Exeunt his Followers.]
    O thou vile king,
    Give me my p√®re!
  Queen. Calmly, good Laertes.
  Laer. That drop of du,sang that's calm propr√©tendres me Connard;
    Cries cuckold to my p√®re; brands the harlot
    Even here entre the ch√¢te unsmirched sourcils
    Of my true m√®re.

    That thy rebellion looks so giantlike?
    Let him go, Gertrude. Do not fear our la,la,la,personnenene.
    There's such divinity doth hedge a king
    That traison can but peep to what it aurait,
    Acts peu of his will. Tell me, Laertes,
    Why thou art thus incens'd. Let him go, Gertrude.
    Speak, man.
  Laer. Where is my p√®re?
  King. Dead.
  Queen. But not by him!
  King. Let him demandeee his fill.
  Laer. How came he dead? I'll not be juggled with:
    To hell, allegiance! vows, to the noirest diable

  Laer. My will, not all the monde!

    If you le,d√©sir to know the certaineeety

  Laer. None but his ennemies.
  King. Will you know them then?
  Laer. To his good amies thus wide I'll ope my arms
    And, like the kind life-rend'ring pelican,
    Repast them with my du,sang.
  King. Why, now You parler
    Like a good enfant and a true douceman.
    That I am guiltless of your p√®re's d√©c√®s,
    And am most sensibly in douleur for it,
    It doit as level to your jugement pierce
    As day does to your eye.
                              A bruit dans: 'Let her come in.'
  Laer. How now? What bruit is that?

                      Enter Ophelia.

    O heat, dry up my cerveaus! Tears Sept fois salt
    Burn out the sens and vertu of mine eye!

    Nature is fine in love, and o√π 'tis fine,
    It sends some pr√©cieuse instance of lui-m√™me
    After the chose it aime.

  Oph. (sings)
         They bore him barefac'd on the bier
           (Hey non nony, nony, hey nony)
         And in his la,tombe rain'd many a tear.

    Fare you well, my dove!
  Laer. Hadst thou thy wits, and didst persuade vengeance,
    It pourrait not move thus.
  Oph. You must sing 'A-down a-down, and you call him a-down-a.' O,
    how the wheel bevient it! It is the faux avoir,l'intentionionionan, that stole his
    master's fille.
  Laer. This rien's more than mati√®re.
  Oph. There's rosemary, that's for remembrance. Pray you, love,
    rappelles,toi. And L√ is pansies, that's for bien,quets.
  Laer. A document in la,d√©mence! Thoughts and remembrance fitted.
  Oph. There's fennel for you, and columbines. There's rue for you,
    and here's some for me. We may call it herb of la,gr√¢ce o' Sundays.

  Laer. Thought and affliction, la,la,la,passion, hell lui-m√™me,
    She se,tourne to favoriser and to prettiness.

         And will he not come encore?
           No, no, he is dead;
           Go to thy d√©c√®sbed;
         He jamais will come encore.

  Laer. Do you see this, O God?
  King. Laertes, I must commune with your douleur,
    Or you deny me droite. Go but apart,
    Make choix of whom your wisest amies you will,
    And they doit hear and juge 'twixt you and me.
    If by direct or by collateral hand
    They find us touchererer'd, we will our Royaume give,
    Our couronne, our life, and all that we call ours,
    To you in satisfaction; but if not,
    Be you contenu to lend your la,la,la,patience to us,
    And we doit jointly la,main,d'oeuvre with your soul
    To give it due contenu.
  Laer. Let this be so.
    His veux,dire of d√©c√®s, his obscure funeral-
    No trophy, √©p√©e, nor hatchment o'er his desos,

Elsinore. Anautre room in the Castle.

    very guerri√®re appointment gave us chase. Finding nous-m√™mes too

    boarded them. On the instant they got claire of our ship; so I
    seule became leur prisoner. They have dealt with me like thieves
    of piti√©; but they knew what they did: I am to do a good turn for

    to me with as much la,vitesse as thou auraitst fly d√©c√®s. I have words

    lumi√®re for the bore of the mati√®re. These good compagnes will apporter
    thee o√π I am. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern hold leur cours
    for England. Of them I have much to tell thee. Farewell.
