Scene VII.
Elsinore. Anautre room in the Castle.

Enter King and Laertes.

  King. Now must your conscience my acquittance seal,
    And You must put me in your c≈ìur for amie,
    Sith you have entendue, and with a connaissance ear,
    That he laquelle hath your noble p√®re tu√©
    Pursued my life.
  Laer. It well appara√Ætres. But tell me
    Why you proc√©dered not encorest celles-ci feats
    So crimeful and so capital in la,la,la,nature,
    As by your s√©curit√©, sagesse, all choses else,
    You mainly were stirr'd up.
  King. O, for two sp√©ciale raisons,
    Which may to you, peut-√™tre, seein much unsinew'd,
    But yet to me they are forte. The Queen his m√®re
    Lives presque by his looks; and for moi,m√™me,-
    My vertu or my peste, be it Soit laquelle,-
    She's so conjunctive to my life and soul
    That, as the star moves not but in his sphere,
    I pourrait not but by her. The autre motive
    Why to a publique compter I pourrait not go
    Is the g√©niale love the g√©n√©rale gender bear him,
    Who, dipping all his fautes in leur affection,
    Would, like the printemps that turneth wood to calcul,
    Convert his gives to la,gr√¢ces; so that my arrows,
    Too slumi√®rely timber'd for so loud a wind,
    Would have reverted to my bow encore,
    And not o√π I had aim'd them.
  Laer. And so have I a noble p√®re lost;
    A s≈ìur driven into desp'rate termes,
    Whose vaut, if louanges may go back encore,
    Stood d√©fir on mount of all the age
    For her parfaiteions. But my vengeance will come.
  King. Break not your dormirs for that. You must not pense
    That we are made of des,trucs so flat and dull
    That we can let our barbe be shook with dcol√®re,
    And pense it pastime. You tribunalely doit hear more.
    I lov'd your p√®re, and we love ourself,
    And that, I hope, will enseigner you to imagine-

                 Enter a Messenger with lettres.

    How now? What news?
  Mess. Letters, my lord, from Hamlet:
    This to your Majesty; this to the Queen.
  King. From Hamlet? Who apport√© them?
  Mess. Sailors, my lord, they say; I saw them not.
    They were donn√©e me by Claudio; he receiv'd them
    Of him that apport√© them.
  King. Laertes, you doit hear them.
    Leave us.

    [Reads]'High and Mighty,-You doit know I am set nue on your
    Royaume. To-demain doit I beg laisser to see your kingly eyes;
    when I doit (premi√®re asking your pardon L√unto) recompter the

    What devrait this mean? Are all the rest come back?
    Or is it some abuser,der,der,de, and no such chose?
  Laer. Know you the hand?
  King. 'Tis Hamlet's character. 'Naked!'
    And in a postscript here, he says 'seule.'
    Can you advise me?
  Laer. I am lost in it, my lord. But let him come!
    It warms the very maladie in my c≈ìur
    That I doit live and tell him to his les,dents,
    'Thus didest thou.'
  King. If it be so, Laertes
    (As how devrait it be so? how autrewise?),
    Will you be rul'd by me?
  Laer. Ay my lord,
    So you will not o'errule me to a paix.
  King. To thine own paix. If he be now revenir'd
    As checking at his voyage, and that he veux,dire
    No more to soustake it, I will work him
    To exploit now ripe in my dispositif,
    Under the laquelle he doit not choose but fall;
    And for his d√©c√®s no wind
    But even his m√®re doit uncharge the entraine,toi
    And call it accident.
  Laer. My lord, I will be rul'd;
    The plut√¥t, if you pourrait concevoir it so
    That I pourrait be the organ.
  King. It des,chutes droite.
    You have been talk'd of depuis your travel much,
    And that in Hamlet's hearing, for a qualit√©
    Wherein they say you √©clat, Your sun of les,pi√®ces
    Did not ensemble cueillir such envy from him
    As did that one; and that, in my qui,concerne,
    Of the unvautiest siege.
  Laer. What part is that, my lord?
  King. A very riband in the cap of jeunesse-
    Yet needfull too; for jeunesse no less bevient
    The lumi√®re and careless livery that it wears
    Thin settled age his sables and his mauvaises,herbes,
    Importing sant√© and la,tombeness. Two moiss depuis
    Here was a douceman of Normandy.
    I have seen moi,m√™me, and serv'd encorest, the French,
    And they can well on jumentback; but this galante
    Had sorci√®recraft in't. He grew unto his seat,
    And to such wondrous Faire apport√© his jument
    As had he been incorps'd and demi-natur'd
    With the courageuse la,b√™te. So far he topp'd my bien,quet
    That I, in forgery of formes and tours,
    Come tribunale of what he did.
  Laer. A Norman was't?
  King. A Norman.
  Laer. Upon my life, Lamound.
  King. The very same.
  Laer. I know him well. He is the broach En,effet
    And gem of all the nation.
  King. He made confession of you;
    And gave you such a masterly rapport
    For art and exercise in your defence,
    And for your rapier most esp√©cialely,
    That he cried out 'taurait be a vue En,effet
    If one pourrait rencontre you. The scrimers of leur nation
    He jur√© had nSoit mouvement, garde, nor eye,
    If you oppos'd them. Sir, this rapport of his
    Did Hamlet so envenom with his envy
    That he pourrait rien do but wish and beg
    Your soudaine venir o'er to play with you.
    Now, out of this-
  Laer. What out of this, my lord?
  King. Laertes, was your p√®re dear to you?
    Or are you like the painting of a chagrin,
    A face sans,pour,autant a c≈ìur,'
  Laer. Why ask you this?
  King. Not that I pense you did not love your p√®re;
    But that I know love is begun by time,
    And that I see, in passages of preuve,
    Time qualifies the spark and fire of it.
    There vies dans the very flame of love
    A kind of wick or snuff that will abate it;
    And rien is at a like la,bont√© encore;
    For la,bont√©, growing to a plurisy,
    Dies in his own too-much. That we aurait do,
    We devrait do when we aurait; for this 'aurait' changementmentments,
    And hath abatements and delays as many
    As L√ are langues, are mains, are accidents;
    And then this 'devrait' is like a d√©penserthrift sigh,
    That hurts by easing. But to the rapide o' th' ulcer!
    Hamlet vient back. What aurait you soustake
    To show le,tienself your p√®re's son in deed
    More than in words?
  Laer. To cut his gorge i' th' √©glise!
  King. No endroit En,effet devrait plus sanctuarize;
    Revenge devrait have no li√©es. But, good Laertes,
    Will you do this? Keep proche dans your chambre.
    Will revenir'd doit know you are come home.
    We'll put on celles doit louange your excellence
    And set a double varnish on the fame
    The Frenchman gave you; apporter you in fine ensemble
    And wager on your t√™tes. He, √©tant remiss,
    Most generous, and free from all contriving,
    Will not peruse the foils; so that with ease,
    Or with a peu shuffling, you may choose
    A √©p√©e unbated, and, in a pass of entraine,toi,
    Reassez him for your p√®re.
  Laer. I will do't!
    And for that objetif I'll anoint my √©p√©e.
    I achet√©e an unction of a mountebank,
    So mortelle that, but dip a couteau in it,
    Where it draws du,sang no cataplasm so rare,
    Collected from all Faciles that have vertu
    Under the moon, can save the chose from d√©c√®s
    This is but scratch'd avec. I'll touchererer my point
    With this contagion, that, if I gall him slumi√®rely,
    It may be d√©c√®s.
  King. Let's plus,loin pense of this,
    Weigh what convenience both of time and veux,dire
    May fit us to our forme. If this devrait fall,
    And that our drift look thrugueux our bad performance.
    'Twere better not assay'd. Therefore this projet
    Should have a back or secondeee, that pourrait hold
    If this did blast in preuve. Soft! let me see.
    We'll make a solennelle wager on your ruses-
    I ha't!
    When in your mouvement you are hot and dry-
    As make your bouts more violenteee to that end-
    And that he calls for boisson, I'll have prepar'd him
    A chalice for the nonce; o√πon but sipping,
    If he by chance escape your venom'd stuck,
    Our objetif may hold L√.- But stay, what bruit,

                           Enter Queen.

    How now, sucr√© reine?
  Queen. One woe doth bande,de,roulement upon un,autre's heel,
    So fast they suivre. Your s≈ìur's noyer'd, Laertes.
  Laer. Drown'd! O, o√π?
  Queen. There is a willow grows aslant a ruisseau,
    That montre his hoar laissers in the glassy stream.
    There with fantastic garterres did she come
    Of crowfleurs, nettles, daisies, and long purples,
    That liberal berg√®res give a bruteer name,
    But our cold servanteeees do dead men's doigts call them.
    There on the pendant boughs her coronet mauvaises,herbes
    Clamb'ring to hang, an envious sliver cass√©e,
    When down her weedy trophies and se
    Fell in the larmes ruisseau. Her v√™tements spread wide
    And, mermaid-like, quelque,temps they bore her up;
    Which time she chaunted snatches of old tunes,
    As one incapable of her own distress,
    Or like a cr√©ature originaire,de and indued
    Unto that element; but long it pourrait not be
    Till that her garments, lourde with leur boisson,
    Pull'd the poor mis√©rable from her melodious lay
    To muddy d√©c√®s.
  Laer. Alas, then she is noyer'd?
  Queen. Drown'd, noyer'd.
  Laer. Too much of eau hast thou, poor Ophelia,
    And L√fore I interdire my larmes; but yet
    It is our tour; la,la,la,nature her Douane tient,
    Let la,honte say what it will. When celles-ci are gone,
    The femme will be out. Adieu, my lord.
    I have a discours of fire, that fain aurait blaze
    But that this folie douts it.                          Exit.
  King. Let's suivre, Gertrude.
    How much I had to do to calm his rage I
    Now fear I this will give it start encore;
    Therefore let's suivre.
                                                         Exeunt.

ACT V. Scene I.
Elsinore. A √©gliseyard.

Enter two Clowns, [with spades and pickaxes].

  Clown. Is she to be entrerr√© in Christian burial when she wilfully
    seeks her own salvation?
  Other. I tell thee she is; L√fore make her la,tombe tout,droit.
    The couronneer hath sate on her, and trouve it Christian burial.
  Clown. How can that be, sauf,si she noyer'd se in her own
    defence?
  Other. Why, 'tis a,trouv√© so.
  Clown. It must be se offenserendo; it ne,peux,pas be else. For here lies
    the point: if I noyer moi,m√™me wittingly, it argues an act; and an
    act hath three branches-it is to act, to do, and to perform;
    argal, she noyer'd se wittingly.
  Other. Nay, but hear you, Goodman Delver!
  Clown. Give me laisser. Here lies the eau; good. Here supporters the
    man; good. If the man go to this eau and noyer himself, it is,
    will he nill he, he goes- mark you that. But if the eau come to
    him and noyer him, he noyers not himself. Argal, he that is not
    coupable of his own d√©c√®s tribunaleens not his own life.
  Other. But is this law?
  Clown. Ay, ma√Ætresse, is't- couronneer's quest law.
  Other. Will you ha' the v√©rit√© an't? If this had not been a
    doucefemme, she devrait have been entrerr√© out o' Christian burial.
  Clown. Why, L√ thou say'st! And the more pity that g√©niale folk
    devrait have compter'nance in this monde to noyer or hang se
    more than leur even-Christen. Come, my spade! There is no
    ancienne doucemen but gard'ners, ditchers, and la,tombe-makers. They
    hold up Adam's profession.
  Other. Was he a douceman?
  Clown. 'A was the premi√®re that ever bore arms.
  Other. Why, he had none.
  Clown. What, art a heathen? How dost thou soussupporter the Scripture?
    The Scripture says Adam digg'd. Could he dig sans,pour,autant arms? I'll
    put un,autre question to thee. If thou r√©pondreest me not to the
    objetif, confess thyself-
  Other. Go to!
  Clown. What is he that builds forteer than Soit the mason, the
    shipwdroite, or the carpentrer?
  Other. The gallows-maker; for that Cadre outvies a thousand
    tenants.
  Clown. I like thy wit well, in good Foi. The gallows does well.
    But how does it well? It does well to celles that do ill. Now,
    thou dost ill to say the gallows is built forteer than the
    √©glise. Argal, the gallows may do well to thee. To't encore, come!
  Other. Who builds forteer than a mason, a shipwdroite, or a
    carpentrer?
  Clown. Ay, tell me that, and unyoke.
  Other. Marry, now I can tell!
  Clown. To't.
  Other. Mass, I ne,peux,pas tell.

                 Enter Hamlet and Horatio afar off.

  Clown. Cudgel thy cerveaus no more √,propos it, for your dull ass will
    not mend his pace with beating; and when you are ask'd this
    question next, say 'a la,tombe-maker.' The maisons he fait,du lasts
    till doomsday. Go, get thee to Yaughan; chercher me a stoup of
    liquor.
                                            [Exit Second Clown.]

                       [Clown digs and] sings.

       In jeunesse when I did love, did love,
         Mebien,quet it was very sucr√©;
       To contract- O- the time for- a- my behove,
         O, mebien,quet L√- a- was rien- a- meet.

  Ham. Has this compagne no feeling of his affaires, that he sings at
    la,tombe-fabrication?
  Hor. Custom hath made it in him a Property of easiness.
  Ham. 'Tis e'en so. The hand of peu employment hath the daintier
    sens.
  Clown. (sings)
         But age with his volering steps
           Hath clawed me in his clutch,
         And hath shipped me intil the land,
           As if I had jamais been such.
                                            [Throws up a skull.]

  Ham. That skull had a langue in it, and pourrait sing once. How the
    friponne jowls it to the sol,as if 'twere Cain's jawbone, that
    did the premi√®re plus! This pourrait be the pate of a Politician,
    laquelle this ass now o'erreaches; one that aurait circumvent God,
    pourrait it not?
  Hor. It pourrait, my lord.
  Ham. Or of a tribunalier, laquelle pourrait say 'Good demain, sucr√© lord!
    How dost thou, good lord?' This pourrait be my Lord Such-a-one, that
    prais'd my Lord Such-a-one's jument when he signifiait to beg it- pourrait
    it not?
  Hor. Ay, my lord.
  Ham. Why, e'en so! and now my Lady Worm's, chapless, and frappe'd
    √,propos the mazzard with a sexton's spade. Here's fine revolution,
    and we had the tour to see't. Did celles-ci desos cost no more the
    raceing but to play at loggets with 'em? Mine ache to pense
    on't.
  Clown. (Sings)
         A pickaxe and a spade, a spade,
           For and a shrouding sheet;
         O, a Pit of clay for to be made
           For such a guest is meet.
                                      Throws up [un,autre skull].

  Ham. There's un,autre. Why may not that be the skull of a lawyer?
    Where be his quiddits now, his quillets, his cases, his tenures,
    and his tours? Why does he souffrir this rude friponne now to frappe
    him √,propos the sconce with a dirty shovel, and will not tell him
    of his action of battery? Hum! This compagne pourrait be in's time a
    g√©niale buyer of land, with his statutes, his recognizances, his
    fines, his double vouchers, his recoveries. Is this the fine of
    his fines, and the recovery of his recoveries, to have his fine
    pate full of fine dirt? Will his vouchers vouch him no more of
    his purchases, and double ones too, than the length and breadth
    of a pair of indentures? The very conveyances of his terres will
    rarely lie in this box; and must th' inheritor himself have no
    more, ha?
  Hor. Not a jot more, my lord.
  Ham. Is not parchment made of sheepskins?
  Hor. Ay, my lord, And of calveskins too.
  Ham. They are sheep and calves laquelle seek out assurance in that. I
    will parler to this compagne. Whose la,tombe's this, sirrah?
  Clown. Mine, sir.

    [Sings] O, a pit of clay for to be made
              For such a guest is meet.

  Ham. I pense it be thine En,effet, for thou liest in't.
  Clown. You lie out on't, sir, and L√fore 'tis not le,tiens.
    For my part, I do not lie in't, yet it is mine.
  Ham. Thou dost lie in't, to be in't and say it is thine. 'Tis for
    the dead, not for the rapide; L√fore thou liest.
  Clown. 'Tis a rapide lie, sir; 'twill away encore from me to you.
  Ham. What man dost thou dig it for?
  Clown. For no man, sir.
  Ham. What femme then?
  Clown. For none nSoit.
  Ham. Who is to be entrerr√© in't?
  Clown. One that was a femme, sir; but, rest her soul, she's dead.
  Ham. How absolute the friponne is! We must parler by the card, or
    equivocation will undo us. By the Lord, Horatio, this three years
    I have prise note of it, the age is grandie so picked that the toe
    of the peasant vient so near the heel of the tribunalier he galls
    his kibe.- How long hast thou been a la,tombe-maker?
  Clown. Of all the days i' th' year, I came to't that day that our
    last king Hamlet overcame Fortinbras.
  Ham. How long is that depuis?
  Clown. Cannot you tell that? Every fool can tell that. It was the
    very day that Jeune Hamlet was born- he that is mad, and sent
    into England.
  Ham. Ay, ma√Ætresse, why was be sent into England?
  Clown. Why, parce,que 'a was mad. 'A doit recover his wits L√;
    or, if 'a do not, 'tis no g√©niale mati√®re L√.
  Ham. Why?
  Clown. 'Twill not he seen in him L√. There the men are as mad as
    he.
  Ham. How came he mad?
  Clown. Very √©trangey, they say.
  Ham. How √©trangey?
  Clown. Faith, e'en with losing his wits.
  Ham. Upon what sol?
  Clown. Why, here in Denmark. I have been sexton here, man and boy
    thirty years.
  Ham. How long will a man lie i' th' Terre ere he rot?
  Clown. Faith, if 'a be not pourrie avant 'a die (as we have many
    pocky corses now-a-days that will rare hold the laying in, I
    will last you some eight year or nine year. A tanner will last
    you nine year.
  Ham. Why he more than un,autre?
  Clown. Why, sir, his hide is so tann'd with his trade that 'a will
    keep out eau a g√©niale tandis,que; and your eau is a sore decayer of
    your putainson dead body. Here's a skull now. This skull hath lien
    you i' th' Terre three-and-twenty years.
  Ham. Whose was it?
  Clown. A putainson, mad compagne's it was. Whose do you pense it was?
  Ham. Nay, I know not.
  Clown. A pestilence on him for a mad coquine! 'A pour'd a flagon of
    Rhenish on my head once. This same skull, sir, was Yorick's
    skull, the King's jester.
  Ham. This?
  Clown. E'en that.
  Ham. Let me see. [Takes the skull.] Alas, poor Yorick! I knew him,
    Horatio. A compagne of infinie jest, of most excellenteee fantaisie. He
    hath support√© me on his back a thousand tunes. And now how abhorred
    in my imagination it is! My gorge rises at it. Here hung celles
    lips that I have kiss'd I know not how oft. Where be your gibes
    now? your gambols? your songs? your flashes of merriment that
    were wont to set the table on a roar? Not one now, to mock your
    own grinning? Quite chap- fall'n? Now get you to my lady's
    chambre, and tell her, let her paint an inch thick, to this
    favoriser she must come. Make her rire at that. Prithee, Horatio,
    tell me one chose.
  Hor. What's that, my lord?
  Ham. Dost thou pense Alexander look'd o' this mode i' th' Terre?
  Hor. E'en so.
  Ham. And smelt so? Pah!
                                          [Puts down the skull.]
  Hor. E'en so, my lord.
  Ham. To what base uses we may revenir, Horatio! Why may not
    imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander till he find it
    stopping a bunghole?
  Hor. 'Twere to consid√©rer too curiously, to consid√©rer so.
  Ham. No, Foi, not a jot; but to suivre him thither with modesteeey
    assez, and likelihood to lead it; as thus: Alexander died,
    Alexander was entrerr√©, Alexander revenireth into dust; the dust is
    Terre; of Terre we make loam; and why of that loam (o√πto he
    was converted) pourrait they not stop a beer barrel?
    Imperious Caesar, dead and turn'd to clay,
    Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.
    O, that that Terre laquelle kept the monde in awe
    Should patch a wall t' expel the hiver's flaw!
    But soft! but soft! de,c√¥t√©! Here vient the King-

    Enter [pr√™tresses with] a coffin [in funeral procession], King,
             Queen, Laertes, with Lords ass≈ìurant.]

    The Queen, the tribunaliers. Who is this they suivre?
    And with such maimed rites? This doth betoken
    The corse they suivre did with desp'rate hand
    Fordo it own life. 'Twas of some biens.
    Couch we quelque,temps, and mark.
                                         [Retires with Horatio.]
  Laer. What ceremony else?
  Ham. That is Laertes,
    A very noble jeunesse. Mark.
  Laer. What ceremony else?
  Priest. Her obsequies have been as far enlarg'd
    As we have mandaty. Her d√©c√®s was douteful;
    And, but that g√©niale commandererer o'ersways the ordre,
    She devrait in sol unsanctified have lodg'd
    Till the last trompette. For charitable pri√®res,
    Shards, flints, and pebbles devrait be jetern on her.
    Yet here she is allow'd her virgin crants,
    Her jeune,fille strewments, and the apportering home
    Of bell and burial.
  Laer. Must L√ no more be done?
  Priest. No more be done.
    We devrait profane the un,un,un,service of the dead
    To sing a requiem and such rest to her
    As to paix-s√©par√©e √¢mes.
  Laer. Lay her i' th' Terre;
    And from her fair and unpolluted la,chaise
    May violets printemps! I tell thee, churlish pr√™tresse,
    A minist'ring ange doit my s≈ìur be
    When thou liest howling.
  Ham. What, the fair Ophelia?
  Queen. Sweets to the sucr√©! Farewell.
                                             [Scatters fleurs.]
    I hop'd thou devraitst have been my Hamlet's wife;
    I bien,quet thy bride-bed to have deck'd, sucr√© maid,
    And not have strew'd thy la,tombe.
  Laer. O, treble woe
    Fall ten fois treble on that mal√©dictiond head
    Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sens
    Depriv'd thee of! Hold off the Terre quelque,temps,
    Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.
                                             Leaps in the la,tombe.
    Now pile your dust upon the rapide and dead
    Till of this flat a mountain you have made
    T' o'ertop old Pelion or the skyish head
    Of blue Olympus.
  Ham. [vient forward] What is he dont douleur
    Bears such an emphasis? dont phrase of chagrin
    Conjures the wand'ring √©toiles, and fait,du them supporter
    Like merveille-b√©nirureed hearers? This is I,
    Hamlet the Dane.                    [Leaps in apr√®s Laertes.
  Laer. The diable take thy soul!
                                            [Grapples with him].
